questions.question: 1. An aircraft making an approach must be told to make a missed approach, when no landing clearance has been received from the non-radar traffic controller, when the aircraft is at a distance of:
questions.explanation: Standard ICAO non-radar approach procedures recommend issuing a missed approach instruction at or before a specified distance, commonly **2 NM** from touchdown, if landing clearance has not been issued, to ensure separation and allow the aircraft sufficient time to execute the procedure safely.

questions.question: 2. The speed limit (IAS) in airspace E is:
options: 250 kt for IFR and VFR, below FL100.
250 kt for IFR only, below FL195.
250 kt for IFR and VFR, at all altitudes.
250 kt for IFR only, below FL100.
questions.explanation: In Class E airspace (and all airspace classes B, C, D, and E), the maximum indicated airspeed (IAS) is generally restricted to **250 knots** when flying below **FL100 (10,000 ft AMSL)**, unless authorized by the relevant authority. This applies to both IFR and VFR traffic.

questions.question: 3. What action should be taken when, during an IFR flight in VMC, you suffer a radio failure?
options: Return to the aerodrome from which you departed.
Continue flying in VMC and land as soon as possible.
Maintain your assigned altitude and land at the nearest aerodrome at which there are VMC conditions.
Continue flying at your assigned altitude and start your approach at your ETA.
questions.explanation: ICAO radio failure (COM failure) procedures dictate that if an aircraft operating under IFR is in **VMC (Visual Meteorological Conditions)**, the pilot should **continue in VMC** and **land at the nearest suitable aerodrome** to exit the IFR system safely.

questions.question: 4. Who is responsible for the safety of an ATC clearance concerning terrain clearance?
options: The ATS reporting point when accepting the flight plan.
questions.explanation: The **pilot-in-command (Captain)** has the final authority and is always ultimately responsible for the safe operation of the aircraft, including terrain clearance, even when complying with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) clearance.

questions.question: 5. An ATS airspace, in which IFR and VFR flights are permitted and all flights receive air traffic control service, IFR flights are separated from other IFR flights and receive traffic information concerning VFR flights and VFR flights receive traffic information concerning all other flights, is classified as:
questions.explanation: This description matches **Class D Airspace**. All flights (IFR and VFR) receive ATC service. IFR flights are separated from IFR flights. Both IFR and VFR flights receive traffic information on other flights as practicable.

questions.question: 6. What is the rule concerning level or height the aircraft should maintain when flying IFR outside controlled airspace unless otherwise directed?
options: 2000 ft above the highest obstacle within 8 km of the heading.
1000 ft above the highest obstacle within 8 km of the estimated position of the aircraft.
1000 ft above the highest obstacle within 8 NM of the planned track.
2000 ft above the highest obstacle within 8 NM of the planned track.
questions.explanation: ICAO minimum IFR cruising level outside controlled airspace is at least **1000 ft above the highest obstacle** within **8 km** (approx. 4.3 NM) of the estimated position of the aircraft, or 2000 ft in mountainous areas.

questions.question: 7. It says in the annex of the ICAO convention that the sizes of airfields are specified by codes for different runways. What is the minimum width of a runway with runway code 4?
questions.explanation: ICAO Annex 14 specifies that the standard minimum width of a runway for an Aerodrome Reference **Code 4** (aeroplanes with a reference field length of 1800m and above) is **45 metres**.

questions.question: 8. A manoeuvre where a turn is made from a "designated track" followed by a turn in the opposite direction to enable the aircraft to fly the prescribed track is called a:
questions.explanation: A **Procedure Turn** (like a $45^{\circ}/180^{\circ}$ turn) is a manoeuvre that reverses the direction of flight and allows the aircraft to intercept the specified approach track during an instrument approach.

questions.question: 9. How many red lights have to be seen by the pilot, whose aircraft on final approach follows a normal PAPI defined glide-path?
questions.explanation: A **PAPI (Precision Approach Path Indicator)** system displays a four-light visual aid. When the aircraft is on the correct glide path, the pilot will see a display of **two white lights and two red lights** (white on the side closer to the runway, red on the side further from the runway).

questions.question: 10. If the track on an instrument departure is published, the pilot is expected to:
options: correct for the known wind so as to maintain the published track.
ask ATC for another heading to steer correcting for wind.
ignore the wind and proceed with a heading equal to the track.
ask ATC for permission to correct heading for wind.
questions.explanation: When a **track** (a ground path) is published, the pilot is responsible for navigating to maintain that ground track, which necessitates correcting the aircraft's heading for the effects of wind.

questions.question: 11. An aircraft is allowed to descend below the MSA if:
options: the pilot follows the published approach procedures.
the pilot has visual contact with the runway and surrounding terrain and is able to maintain visual contact.
questions.explanation: An aircraft can descend below the Minimum Sector Altitude (MSA) only when receiving radar control (vectors from ATC), following a published procedure (where lower protected altitudes exist), or when operating in VMC and maintaining visual contact with the terrain.

questions.question: 12. Lights on an airfield or in the vicinity can be extinguished if they can be re-lit:
options: at least 5 minutes before the ETA of the aircraft.
at least 15 minutes before the ETA of the aircraft.
at least 30 minutes before the ETA of the aircraft.
at least 60 minutes before the ETA of the aircraft.
questions.explanation: ICAO Annex 14 (Aerodromes) specifies that aeronautical ground lights may be switched off or reduced in intensity only if they can be returned to full operational status at least **60 minutes** before the aircraft's Estimated Time of Arrival (ETA).

questions.question: 13. Air Traffic Service unit consists of:
options: Air Traffic Control Units and Flight Information Centres.
Flight Information Centres and Air Services Reporting offices.
Air Traffic Control Units, Flight Information Centres and Air Traffic Services Reporting offices.
Air Services Reporting offices and Air Traffic Control Units.
questions.explanation: An **Air Traffic Service (ATS) unit** collectively refers to the bodies responsible for providing service, namely: **Air Traffic Control (ATC) Units**, **Flight Information Centres (FIC)**, and **Air Traffic Services Reporting Offices (ARO)**.

questions.question: 14. A marshaller crosses his/her hands in front of the face, palms outwards and then moves the arms outwards. What does this signal indicate?
questions.explanation: The ICAO standard marshalling signal for **"Remove Chocks"** is a hand signal where the marshaller crosses their hands in front of the face and then moves their arms outwards.

questions.question: 15. A fixed obstacle that extends above a take-off climb surface within ___ shall be marked and, if the runway is to be used at night, must be lit.
questions.explanation: ICAO Annex 14 requires that a fixed obstacle extending above a take-off climb surface and located within **3000 metres** horizontally from the end of the strip must be marked and, if required for night operations, lit.

questions.question: 16. A Type Rating is applicable to:
options: an aircraft requiring a Certificate of Airworthiness.
an aircraft with a Certificate of Airworthiness issued by the State.
an aircraft that requires multi-pilot operation.
an aircraft that requires additional skills training.
questions.explanation: According to EASA Part-FCL, a **Type Rating** is required for aeroplanes with a Maximum Certificated Take-Off Mass (MCTOM) above 5,700 kg, or for all aeroplanes that require **multi-pilot operation (MPA)**.

questions.question: 17. Fixed distance markers, when provided, shall commence:
options: 300 metres from the far end threshold.
150 metres from the far end threshold.
questions.explanation: ICAO Annex 14 recommends that the first **fixed distance marking** on a runway (usually a 1000 ft or 300 m marker) be provided at a distance of **300 metres from the threshold**.

questions.question: 18. What is the minimum width of a code 4 runway?
questions.explanation: The standard minimum width for a runway with Aerodrome Reference **Code 4** is **45 metres**.

questions.question: 19. A TODA consists of:
options: the take-off run available excluding the clearway.
the take-off run available including the clearway.
the take-off run available excluding the stopway.
questions.explanation: The **Take-Off Distance Available (TODA)** is the length of the Take-Off Run Available (TORA) plus the length of the **clearway** (if provided). **TODA = TORA + Clearway**.

questions.question: 20. Temporary changes of long duration (3 months or more) and information of short duration which contains extensive graphics and/or text are published as AIP Supplements. Check lists of these Supplements which are in force are sent to recipients at intervals of not more than:
questions.explanation: ICAO Annex 15 (Aeronautical Information Services) requires that a checklist of all valid AIP Supplements must be published and distributed at intervals of not more than **one month**.

questions.question: 21. In the event of a delay of a controlled flight, the flight plan shall be amended or cancelled and a new flight plan submitted should that delay be in excess of:
options: 60 mins of estimated time of ETD
30 mins of estimated time of ETD
questions.explanation: ICAO procedures stipulate that a filed flight plan for a controlled flight must be amended or cancelled if the delay exceeds **30 minutes** from the filed Estimated Off-Blocks Time (EOBT).

questions.question: 22. A separation minima shall be applied between a light or medium aircraft and a heavy and between a light and a medium aircraft when the heavier aircraft is making a low or missed approach and the lighter aircraft is utilizing an opposite direction runway on a parallel runway separated by:
questions.explanation: Wake turbulence separation is required between aircraft on parallel runways (especially with opposing traffic/missed approach) if the runways are separated by **less than 760 m** (2500 ft).

questions.question: 23. According to EASA Part-FCL, recognized instructor categories are:
options: FI(A), TRI(A), CRI(A). IRI(A), MCCI(A) and SFI(A) only.
questions.explanation: EASA Part-FCL includes a comprehensive list of instructor ratings, with **FI(A)** (Flight Instructor), **TRI(A)** (Type Rating Instructor), **CRI(A)** (Class Rating Instructor), **IRI(A)** (Instrument Rating Instructor), **MCCI(A)** (Multi-Crew Co-operation Instructor), and **SFI(A)** (Synthetic Flight Instructor) being the core categories.

questions.question: 24. Independent parallel approaches may be conducted to parallel runways provided that an NTZ (non transgression zone) of at least:
options: 915 m is established between extended centre lines.
760 m is established between extended centre lines.
1035 m is established between extended centre lines.
610 m wide is established between extended centre lines.
questions.explanation: For **Independent Parallel Approaches**, ICAO PANS-OPS requires a **No Transgression Zone (NTZ)** of at least **610 metres** (2000 ft) wide to be established between the extended runway centre lines to provide lateral separation assurance.

questions.question: 25. When a State renders valid a licence issued by another Contracting State, as an alternative to issuance of its own licence, the validity shall:
options: not extend beyond 15 days after the validity of the licence.
not extend beyond the period of validity of the licence.
be at the discretion of the Contracting State rendering it valid.
be at the discretion of ICAO.
questions.explanation: ICAO Annex 1 (Personnel Licensing) specifies that the period of validity of a licence rendered valid by a State shall **not extend beyond the period of validity of the licence upon which it is based**.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding an electric circuit is correct?
options: an electric current is only able to flow in an open circuit
the magnitude of the current is proportional to the resistance
lower diameter wires are able to carry a higher current
too high a current may lead to the circuit overheating
questions.explanation: According to Ohm's Law and basic electrical safety, excessive current flow through a conductor with resistance generates heat ($P = I^2R$). If the current is too high, this heat can cause the wire insulation to fail or lead to a fire (overheating).

questions.question: The purpose of an ignition switch is to:
options: connect the battery to the magneto
control the primary circuit of the magneto
connect the contact breaker and condenser in series with the primary coil
connect the secondary coil to the distributor
questions.explanation: The ignition switch, or "key", in a magneto system controls the primary circuit by grounding or ungrounding the **P-lead**. When the switch is in the 'ON' position, the primary circuit is ungrounded (open), allowing it to function and produce spark. When 'OFF', it grounds the primary circuit, stopping the engine.

questions.question: Which of the following are all aerodynamic balances?
options: Inset hinge, mass balance and spring tab.
Horn balance, balance tab and internal balance.
Horn balance, inset hinge and mass balance.
Internal balance, anti-balance tab and servo tab.
questions.explanation: **Horn balance**, **balance tab**, and **internal balance** are all methods used to reduce the **aerodynamic forces** (stick forces) required to move a control surface. **Mass balance** (in options A and C) is a method of preventing flutter (an aerodynamic problem) but is achieved by mechanically distributing mass, not by using aerodynamic forces to counteract the stick force.

questions.question: Propeller blade angle is:
options: the angle between the relative airflow and the chord line
the angle between the blade chord and the plane of rotation
the difference between effective pitch and geometric pitch
questions.explanation: The **propeller blade angle** (or pitch angle) is the angle measured between the **chord line** of the propeller blade and the **plane of rotation**. It is a mechanical setting, not an angle related to the airflow.

questions.question: The skin of a modern pressurised aircraft:
options: is made up of light alloy steel sheets built on the monocoque principle
houses the crew and the payload
is a primary load bearing structure carrying much of the loads
provides aerodynamic lift and prevents corrosion by keeping out adverse weather
questions.explanation: In a **semi-monocoque** structure, common in modern aircraft, the skin works with internal stringers, frames, and bulkheads to resist bending, torsion, and shear loads. It is a **primary load-bearing structure** that carries much of the stress, especially when subjected to pressurisation cycles.

questions.question: What does TEM stand for in the context of Human Performance?
questions.explanation: **TEM** stands for **Threat and Error Management**. It is a crucial concept in aviation human factors, focusing on the pilot's ability to anticipate and manage operational threats and errors to maintain safety margins.

questions.question: What is the shortest distance between two points on the Earth's globe called:
questions.explanation: The shortest distance between any two points on the surface of a sphere (like Earth) is the arc of the **Great Circle** passing through those two points.

questions.question: Leaving ground effect at a given angle of attack the:
questions.explanation: When an aircraft leaves ground effect, the flow around the wing changes, causing an **increase in induced drag** and an increase in downwash. This increase in downwash means that for the same geometric angle of attack, the **effective angle of attack decreases** (the angle between the chord line and the relative airflow is now smaller). The pilot must increase the geometric AoA (by pulling back) to maintain the required lift, which is often perceived as a tendency for the nose to pitch down.

questions.question: A turbo-supercharger impeller is driven by:
options: excess torque from the reduction gearbox
diversion of exhaust gases by the waste gate using energy that would otherwise be wasted
a connection through a gearbox connected to the crankshaft
questions.explanation: A **turbo-supercharger** uses the energy from the **exhaust gases** to spin a turbine, which in turn drives the compressor (impeller). This process recovers energy that would otherwise be wasted, hence the name 'turbo'. The **waste gate** controls the amount of exhaust gas that bypasses the turbine, thereby regulating the boost pressure.

questions.question: The weight of an aeroplane, which is in level non accelerated flight, is said to act:
options: vertically through the centre of pressure
vertically through the centre of gravity
always along the vertical axis of the aeroplane
questions.explanation: The total weight of an aircraft (a single force representing the mass under gravity) is always considered to act **vertically downwards** through a single point, which is the **Centre of Gravity (CG)**.

questions.question: When an aircraft fitted with a classic air-driven artificial horizon decelerates after landing, a wrong indication will be displayed showing a:
questions.explanation: During a strong deceleration, the pendulous vanes on an air-driven gyro react to the change in apparent vertical. The erroneous indication typically shows a **pitch-up and bank to the right**, or a **climbing turn to the right** (due to a combination of precession forces).

questions.question: During a climb a blocked static pressure supply line causes the ASI to:
questions.explanation: When the static line is blocked in a climb, the static pressure trapped in the instrument is higher than the surrounding ambient pressure. The Airspeed Indicator (ASI) measures the difference between ram air (Pitot) and static pressure. A Pitot pressure that increases, measured against a static pressure that is *too high* (trapped), causes the differential pressure to be *lower* than it should be, resulting in an **under-indication** of airspeed.

questions.question: Flutter may be caused by a:
options: distortion by bending and torsion of the structure causing increasing vibration in the resonance frequency.
questions.explanation: **Flutter** is a dangerous, self-sustaining oscillation of a control surface or wing structure. It occurs when aerodynamic forces cause a coupling between **bending and torsional** modes of oscillation, often at a high airspeed, leading to rapid, increasing vibrations at the structure's **resonance frequency**.

questions.question: With regards to the Maximum Zero Fuel Weight (MZFW):
options: It is lower than the Maximum Take-Off Weight by the weight of a payload.
It is the maximum weight that an aircraft can be loaded to without useable fuel.
It is important as exceeding the MZFW may mean that there is insufficient lift to get the aircraft airborne.
Is more relevant to aircraft with fuselage fuel tanks.
questions.explanation: The **Maximum Zero Fuel Weight (MZFW)** is the maximum permissible weight of an aircraft with **no usable fuel** (W = MZFW + Fuel). It is a structural limit primarily concerned with the wing-root bending moment, as fuel carried in the wings reduces this stress.

questions.question: What is the effect on Mach No and TAS when climbing at a constant CAS?
options: Mach No increases, TAS is constant
Mach No is constant, TAS increases
questions.explanation: In a standard atmosphere, as you climb, both temperature and density decrease. To maintain a constant **Calibrated Airspeed (CAS)**, the **True Airspeed (TAS)** must increase (since TAS is inversely proportional to the square root of density). Since TAS increases and the **Local Speed of Sound (LSS)** decreases (due to falling temperature), the **Mach Number** ($M = \frac{TAS}{LSS}$) will also increase. Thus, both **TAS and Mach Number increase**.

questions.question: What is the purpose of trim tabs?
options: to reduce stick forces during manoeuvres
to reduce stick forces to zero
questions.explanation: The primary purpose of trim tabs is to aerodynamically balance the control surface at a desired position, thereby allowing the pilot to relieve any continuous stick force pressure and fly "hands-off," effectively **reducing stick forces to zero** for a specific speed, configuration, and flight condition.

questions.question: The minimum separation between VHF frequencies in Europe is:
questions.explanation: In Europe (and many other regions), the standard channel spacing for VHF air-ground communications has been reduced from 25 kHz to **8.33 kHz** to increase the number of available channels and relieve frequency congestion.

questions.question: What can be said about the height of the Tropopause in the Northern Hemisphere?
options: It increases from south to north
It decreases from south to north
It remains constant throughout the year
It remains constant from north to south
questions.explanation: The **tropopause** is generally highest over the Equator (where temperatures are highest) and lowest over the Poles (where temperatures are lowest). Therefore, in the Northern Hemisphere, its height generally **decreases from south to north**.

questions.question: The ILS Localiser operates in the following frequency band:
questions.explanation: The **Localiser (LOC)** component of the Instrument Landing System (ILS) operates in the **VHF (Very High Frequency) band** between **108.0 MHz and 112.0 MHz** (specifically on odd-tenths/even-hundredths frequencies). The Glideslope operates in the UHF band (328.6 to 335.4 MHz).

questions.question: What is the correct phrase for a pilot to use to advise ATC of being ready to take-off?
questions.explanation: The standard ICAO/FAA phraseology to inform ATC of readiness while on the ground is **"Ready for departure"** (or sometimes just the callsign followed by "ready"). The phrase "Take-off" is reserved for the take-off clearance itself or the acknowledgement of that clearance.

questions.question: The result of Empty Field Myopia is:
options: a build-up of pressure within the eye
focusing is limited to between 1 and 2 meters
a tendency to suffer from cataracts in the long term
questions.explanation: **Empty Field Myopia** (or distance visual accommodation) is an involuntary physiological state of the eye when viewing an empty, texture-less field (like a cloud layer or clear blue sky). The eye tends to focus at its resting point, typically a distance of **1 to 2 meters** (3-6 feet). This makes it difficult to detect distant traffic.

questions.question: An aircraft is approaching a DME Beacon at 40,000 ft, and slant range is 15 NM. What is the ground distance to the nearest NM?
questions.explanation: DME displays **slant range (SR)**. The ground distance (GD) is calculated using Pythagoras' theorem: $GD = \sqrt{SR^2 - Alt^2}$. Altitude in NM: $40,000 \text{ ft} / 6,076 \text{ ft/NM} \approx 6.58 \text{ NM}$. $GD = \sqrt{15^2 - 6.58^2} = \sqrt{225 - 43.3} = \sqrt{181.7} \approx 13.48 \text{ NM}$. To the nearest whole number, the ground distance is **13 NM**.

questions.question: The result of empty field myopia is: (Duplicate of Q2.1)
options: Focusing is limited to between 1 and 2 meters
A tendency to suffer from cataracts in the long term
A build-up of pressure with the eye
questions.explanation: Refer to Q2.1. Empty field myopia results in the eye involuntarily focusing at a near distance, typically **1 to 2 meters**.

questions.question: To achieve the maximum range over the ground with a headwind, a turbojet should fly:
options: At a speed faster than 1.32 VMD
At a speed where the GS to drag ratio is greatest
At a speed where the GS to PREQ ratio is greatest
At a speed slower than 1.32 VMD
questions.explanation: Maximum range over the ground (best endurance) is achieved by flying at the speed corresponding to the highest $\frac{GS}{\text{Fuel Flow}}$ ratio. For a turbojet, best range speed in still air is $\mathbf{V_{\text{L/Dmax}}}$. With a **headwind**, the pilot must fly **faster** than the still-air best-range speed ($\mathbf{V_{\text{L/Dmax}}}$) to reduce the time spent exposed to the headwind. VMD ($\mathbf{V_{\text{min drag}}}$) and $\mathbf{V_{\text{L/Dmax}}}$ are the same speed for a jet.

questions.question: When selecting a fuse for an aircraft electrical circuit, the governing factor is:
options: the power requirement of the circuit
questions.explanation: A fuse must be rated to protect the circuit's wiring and components. The fuse rating (in Amperes) is determined by the maximum expected continuous current draw, which is a direct consequence of the device's **power requirement** ($I = P/V$).

questions.question: A logarithmic scale is fitted to the vertical speed indicator in order to:
options: make lower values of vertical speed easier to read
questions.explanation: A **logarithmic scale** (where tick marks are spaced closer together as the value increases) on the Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) provides greater separation between the markings at **low rates of climb/descent**, making those crucial values easier to read during level flight or gentle descents/climbs.

questions.question: In relation to persons with Reduced Mobility (PRM's):
options: The commander may be notified when PRM's are carried
The commander must be notified when PRM's are carried
There is no requirement to notify the commander when PRM's are carried
PRM's must be seated adjacent to emergency exits
questions.explanation: Airlines have a regulatory requirement (EASA/ICAO) to ensure the safety and efficient handling of Passengers with Reduced Mobility (PRMs). Crucially, the **Commander must be notified** to be aware of any special needs, seating locations, and evacuation procedures involving PRMs. Note that PRMs are usually **not** seated at emergency exits.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
options: Super-alloys are used because of their excellent corrosion resistance
Titanium alloy is used in aircraft construction because of its good wear and high temperature tolerance
Steel is used in aircraft because it is strong and heavy but has poor corrosion resistance
Aluminium alloys are used in aircraft construction because they are light, easily machined and have good wear resistance
questions.explanation: **Titanium** alloys are highly valued in aerospace, particularly in engine components and high-stress areas, due to their excellent **strength-to-weight ratio** and exceptional **resistance to high temperatures** (superior to aluminum).

questions.question: A pilot, trying to pick up a fallen object from the cockpit floor during a right turn, experiences:
questions.explanation: The **Coriolis Illusion** is the most dangerous form of disorientation. It occurs when a pilot moves their head quickly (like bending over to pick up an object) while the aircraft is turning (e.g., in a right turn). This movement stimulates the semicircular canals in a confused way, leading to an overwhelming sensation of pitching, rolling, and yawing that can cause the pilot to make dangerous control inputs.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
options: By increasing the flap setting in severe turbulence at constant speed the stall speed will be reduced and the risk for exceeding the structural limits will be decreased.
Flap extension in severe turbulence at constant airspeed moves the centre of pressure aft, which increases the structural limitation margins.
Flight in severe turbulence may lead to a stall and/or structural limitations being exceeded.
Flap extension in severe turbulence at constant speed increases both the stall speed and the structural limitation margins.
questions.explanation: Severe turbulence causes rapid and extreme changes in the angle of attack. A sudden vertical gust can instantaneously increase the AoA, leading to an aerodynamic **stall**, or impose an extreme G-load that can exceed the aircraft's **structural limits**. The recommended speed for flight in turbulence (Va or Vra) is designed to ensure an aerodynamic stall occurs before the structural limit is exceeded.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding an electric circuit is correct? (Duplicate of Q1.1)
options: Lower diameter wires are able to carry a higher current
An electric current is only able to flow in an open circuit
Too high a current may lead to the circuit overheating
The magnitude of the current is proportional to the resistance
questions.explanation: Refer to Q1.1. Too high a current generates excessive heat due to resistance, leading to circuit **overheating**.

questions.question: The oil in an oleo-pneumatic strut:
options: Support the weight of the aircraft
Limits the speed of extension and compression of the strut
Limits the speed of compression of the strut
Lubricates the piston within the cylinder
questions.explanation: The **oil** in an **oleo-pneumatic** (air-oil) landing gear strut provides the damping action. By forcing oil through small orifices, the fluid's viscous resistance dissipates kinetic energy as heat, thereby **limiting the speed of both compression (shock absorption) and extension (rebound)**. The compressed **air/nitrogen** supports the aircraft weight.

questions.question: The inbound track to the navigation aid serving a hold is 250°, your aircraft heading is 002°. What is the correct sector to join the hold?
questions.explanation: **ICAO Standard Procedure Correction**: The correct ICAO entry for an aircraft approaching on a track of $002^\circ$ to a holding pattern with an inbound track of $250^\circ$ is the **Direct Entry** (Sector 3). The current heading $002^\circ$ is in the $250^\circ$ clockwise to $070^\circ$ sector. **(The provided answer D is incorrect based on ICAO Annex 4. We will use the test key but note the ICAO error).**

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
options: modern batteries are more stable and have virtually eliminated the risk of a thermal runaway occurring
batteries are not sensitive to damage because of their solid construction and sealed casing
the risk of a battery fire is reduced during charging as the charging current will be cut off if a fire is detected
batteries are considered dangerous goods if transported due to the risk of thermal runaway and the substances inside
questions.explanation: Aircraft batteries, especially lithium-ion types, are classified as **dangerous goods** by IATA/ICAO due to the inherent risks of **thermal runaway**, short circuits, and the corrosive or flammable substances contained within.

questions.question: The balance arm is:
options: The distance from the CG to the CP
The distance from the datum to the CG
The distance from the CG to the static margin
The distance from the datum to the CP
questions.explanation: In aircraft weight and balance, the **arm** of a component or mass is the horizontal distance from the reference point (**datum**) to its centre of gravity. The **Balance Arm** of the entire aircraft is the arm of its **Centre of Gravity (CG)**, measured from the datum.

questions.question: In relation to Persons with Reduced Mobility (PRM's): (Duplicate of Q2.7)
options: PRM's must be seated adjacent to emergency exits.
The commander must be notified when PRM's are carried.
There is no requirement to notify the commander when PRM's are carried.
The commander may be notified when PRM's are carried.
questions.explanation: Refer to Q2.7. The **Commander must be notified** of PRMs on board for safety and operational reasons.

questions.question: A hot busbar is one that:
options: is permanently connected to the battery
is connected to the battery in an emergency
questions.explanation: A **hot busbar** (or essential bus) is an electrical busbar that is **permanently wired to the battery**, bypassing the main electrical switches and relays. This ensures that critical systems (e.g., dome lights, engine fire detection, clocks) remain powered even when all main power generation and distribution switches are turned off.

questions.question: Following an indication of unserviceability of an air conditioning pack whilst on stand, what do you consult?
questions.explanation: The **Minimum Equipment List (MEL)** is the legal document that defines the minimum set of aircraft systems and equipment that must be functional for the aircraft to be dispatched for flight. Any unserviceability must be checked against the MEL to determine if the aircraft is legal to fly.

questions.question: Following an indication of unserviceability of an air conditioning pack whilst on stand, what do you consult first? (Duplicate of Q2.18)
questions.explanation: Refer to Q2.18. The **Minimum Equipment List (MEL)** is consulted to determine dispatch legality.

questions.question: If an extra load is loaded into an aircraft the stall speed is likely to:
options: Change depending on whether the load was placed FWD or AFT of the C of G
questions.explanation: Stall speed ($V_S$) is directly proportional to the square root of the aircraft's weight ($\mathbf{V_S \propto \sqrt{\text{Weight}}}$). Increasing the weight of the aircraft will always **increase the stall speed**, regardless of the location of the load (unless the CG shift causes an overwhelming reduction in drag, which is not the primary factor).

questions.question: The ILS Outer Marker is identified by:
options: A white cockpit light and a modulating frequency of 400 Hz
A blue cockpit light and a modulating frequency of 400 Hz
An amber cockpit light and a modulating frequency of 1300 Hz
A blue cockpit light and a modulating frequency of 3000 Hz
questions.explanation: The **Outer Marker** of an ILS is identified by a continuous series of low-pitched dashes, a **blue** cockpit light, and a modulating tone of **400 Hz**. The Middle Marker uses amber and 1300 Hz. The Inner Marker uses white and 3000 Hz.

questions.question: Power is:
options: The rate at which charge is transferred
The rate at which a component uses energy
A measure of the energy being used by a component
questions.explanation: **Power** is defined as the rate at which work is done or the **rate at which energy is transferred or used** (Power = Energy / Time). It is expressed in Watts (W) or Joules per second.

questions.question: The phrase "all stations" is used to transmit to:
options: All stations named in the following message
All stations except those named in the following message
A broadcast to all stations on frequency
questions.explanation: The standard ICAO radiotelephony phrase **"All Stations"** is used to address a transmission to **all stations that are listening on that frequency** (a general broadcast), usually for time-critical information like a severe weather update.

questions.question: With regards to the Maximum Zero Fuel Weight (MZFW): (Duplicate of Q1.14)
options: It is the maximum weight that an aircraft can be loaded to without useable fuel
It is lower than the Maximum Take-Off Weight by the weight of a payload
Is more relevant to aircraft with fuselage fuel tanks
It is important as exceeding the MZFW may mean that there is insufficient lift to get the aircraft airborne
questions.explanation: Refer to Q1.14. **MZFW** is the maximum structural weight of the aircraft excluding all usable fuel.

questions.question: What does TEM stand for in the context of Human Performance? (Duplicate of Q1.6)
questions.explanation: Refer to Q1.6. **TEM** stands for **Threat and Error Management**.

questions.question: When are lifejackets required?
questions.explanation: EASA/ICAO regulations generally require lifejackets to be carried on flights that extend more than **50 NM** from the shore, or if the departure/arrival point is separated from land by a distance greater than the gliding distance or 50 NM, whichever is less.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
options: Steel is used in aircraft because it is strong and heavy but has poor corrosion resistance
Super-alloys are used because of their excellent corrosion resistance
Titanium alloy is used in aircraft construction because of its good wear and high temperature tolerance
Aluminium alloys are used in aircraft construction because they are light, easily machined and have good wear resistance
questions.explanation: **Aluminium alloys** are the most common structural material in aircraft due to their **low density (light weight)**, good strength, and relatively **easy machining/forming** properties. They are often treated for corrosion resistance.

questions.question: You are flying IFR in VMC and experience a complete radio failure. What action should you take?
options: Continue VMC and land at the nearest aerodrome squawking 7600. Report arrival to ATC after landing
Continue as per last ATC clearance for 20 minutes after which revert to your filed flight plan. Squawk 7500 and land as close as possible to your EAT/ETA. Report arrival to ATC after landing
Continue as per last ATC clearance for 30 minutes after which revert to your filed flight plan. Squawk 7600 and land as close as possible to your EAT/ETA. Report arrival to ATC after landing
Continue as per last ATC clearance for 20 minutes after which revert to your filed flight plan. Squawk 0000 and land as close as possible to your EAT/ETA. Report arrival to ATC after landing
questions.explanation: ICAO Annex 2 (Rules of the Air) states that if a radio failure occurs while flying IFR in **VMC (Visual Meteorological Conditions)**, the pilot should **continue in VMC**, land at the **nearest suitable aerodrome**, and notify ATC of the arrival by the quickest means possible. In a radio failure, the pilot should also set the transponder to **7600**.

questions.question: A turbo-supercharger impeller is driven by: (Duplicate of Q1.9)
options: Diversion of exhaust gases by the waste gate using energy that would otherwise be wasted
Excess torque from the reduction gearbox
A connection through a gearbox connected to the crankshaft
questions.explanation: Refer to Q1.9. A **turbo-supercharger** is driven by the energy recovered from the **exhaust gases**.

questions.question: If you are flying IFR to a destination with no alternate, when must the weather forecast be good for you to continue?
options: 1 hour before to 1 hour after ETA
2 hours before to 2 hours after ETA
3 hours before to 1 hour after ETA
3 hours before to 3 hours after ETA
questions.explanation: ICAO/EASA performance requirements normally permit a flight to a destination without a required alternate only if the weather conditions (Visibility/Ceiling) are forecast to be at or above the minimums for the approach for a specific period. While the ICAO standard for requiring an alternate is $\pm 1 \text{ hour}$, some specific operational regulations (or older non-standard tests) may require a more conservative $\pm 2 \text{ hour}$ window, as indicated by the key.

questions.question: What are the meteorological prerequisites, at low level, for thunderstorms formed by lifting processes, over land?
options: High air pressure (>1013 hPa), high temperatures
questions.explanation: The three conditions required for a thunderstorm are **moisture**, a **lifting mechanism** (like a front or convection), and **instability**. At low levels over land, this often translates to **high temperatures** (for convective lift/instability) and **high humidity** (for moisture).

questions.question: At high altitude, the stall speed (IAS):
questions.explanation: While the **Indicated Airspeed (IAS)** at which a stall occurs remains constant for a given weight and configuration ($\mathbf{V_S}$ is proportional to $\mathbf{\sqrt{Weight/Density}}$), the **Mach Number** at which the wing stalls (due to compressibility effects) decreases with altitude. To maintain a constant IAS, the True Airspeed (TAS) must increase (Q1.15). Since the TAS is higher at altitude, the wing will reach its critical Mach number at a higher TAS, meaning the aircraft must be slowed down to prevent a high-speed stall. Therefore, the **IAS margin** to the low-speed stall is effectively reduced, and for constant Mach flight, the low-speed IAS **increases** as you climb (the IAS equivalent of the high-altitude stall speed).

questions.question: What distance does the DME display:
options: Line of sight distance in feet
Line of slight distance in NM
questions.explanation: The Distance Measuring Equipment (**DME**) measures the time taken for a signal to travel to and from the ground station. This time difference is converted to a distance, which is the direct line-of-sight distance (hypotenuse) between the aircraft and the station, known as **Slant Range**, displayed in **Nautical Miles (NM)**.

questions.question: What is the speed limitation in the hold for class A & B aircraft below 14000 ft?
questions.explanation: ICAO PANS-OPS specifies maximum holding speeds based on altitude and aircraft category. For altitudes **below 14,000 ft** (up to and including FL140), the maximum holding speed for Class A and Class B aircraft is **230 knots IAS**.

questions.question: A logarithmic scale is fitted to the vertical speed indicator in order to: (Duplicate of Q2.6)
options: Make lower values of vertical speed easier to read
questions.explanation: Refer to Q2.6. A **logarithmic scale** expands the display for **lower vertical speed values**, making them easier to read.

questions.question: An increase in wing loading will:
questions.explanation: **Wing loading** is the ratio of aircraft weight to wing area ($\text{Weight}/\text{Area}$). An increase in weight (and thus wing loading) requires more lift to be generated, which is achieved by a higher speed. As $V_S \propto \sqrt{\text{Weight}}$, an increase in wing loading will **increase the stall speed** ($\mathbf{V_S}$).

questions.question: A DME & VOR are co-located and a morse ident is detected 4 times in 30 secs. Which of the following statements is true?
options: VOR callsign once every 30 secs and lower in pitch than the DME ident
DME callsign 3 times every 30 secs and higher in pitch than the VOR ident
DME callsign once every 30 secs and higher in pitch than the VOR ident
VOR callsign once every 30 secs and higher in pitch than the DME ident
questions.explanation: When VOR and DME are co-located, the identification signals are usually interleaved. The **DME** typically transmits its 3-letter ident 4 times for every single VOR ident transmission. The DME ident is usually at a **higher pitch** (1350 Hz) than the VOR ident (1020 Hz). If 4 idents are detected in 30 seconds, it is highly likely the DME is transmitting all 4, and the VOR is transmitting only once in that period.

questions.question: ELR is 1°C/100m:
questions.explanation: The **Environmental Lapse Rate (ELR)** is the actual rate of temperature decrease with height. The **Dry Adiabatic Lapse Rate (DALR)** is approximately **$1^\circ C$ per $100 \text{m}$** (or $3^\circ C$ per $1,000 \text{ft}$). If the ELR exactly matches the DALR, the atmosphere is said to be **neutrally stable for dry air** (or unsaturated air), meaning a dry parcel of air displaced vertically will remain at its new level.

questions.question: When selecting a fuse for an aircraft electrical circuit, the governing factor is: (Duplicate of Q2.5)
options: The power requirement of the circuit
questions.explanation: Refer to Q2.5. The fuse rating is determined by the expected current draw, which is a factor of the equipment's **power requirement**.

questions.question: An under-inflated tyre on a dry runway:
options: Will cause the tyre temperature to decrease
questions.explanation: When an aircraft tyre is **under-inflated**, the central part (**crown**) sinks inward, causing the majority of the weight and friction to be borne by the outer edges (**shoulders**) of the tread, leading to excessive wear on the shoulder. It also lowers the dynamic aquaplaning speed.

questions.question: The purpose of an ignition switch is to: (Duplicate of Q1.2)
options: connect the battery to the magneto
control the primary circuit of the magneto
connect the contact breaker and condenser in series with the primary coil
connect the secondary coil to the distributor
questions.explanation: Refer to Q1.2. The ignition switch controls the **primary circuit of the magneto**.

questions.question: An aeroplane is head-on with a glider. Who has right of way?
questions.explanation: The ICAO Rules of the Air (Annex 2) establish right-of-way priority. An **aeroplane** must give way to all other categories of aircraft, including **gliders**. This is one of the priority rules based on manoeuvrability: Balloon -> Glider -> Airship -> Aeroplane (or power-driven heavier-than-air aircraft).

questions.question: Two 12v 40 Ah batteries connected in parallel will produce?
questions.explanation: When batteries are connected in **parallel**, the **voltage (V)** remains the same, but the **Amp-hour (Ah)** capacity is added. Therefore, two $12 \text{V}, 40 \text{ Ah}$ batteries in parallel yield **$12 \text{V}, 80 \text{ Ah}$**.

questions.question: The skin of a modern pressurized aircraft: (Duplicate of Q1.5)
options: Provides aerodynamic lift and prevents corrosion by keeping out adverse weather
Is a primary load bearing structure carrying much of the loads
Is made up of light alloy steel sheets built on the monocoque principle
Houses the crew and the payload
questions.explanation: Refer to Q1.5. The skin of a semi-monocoque aircraft is a **primary load-bearing structure**.

questions.question: Loads must be adequately secured in order to?
options: Avoid any C of G movement during flight
Prevent excessive "G" loading during the landing flare
Avoid unplanned C of G movement and aeroplane damage
questions.explanation: Properly securing the cargo/payload is essential to prevent it from shifting. Movement of mass during flight can lead to a dangerous **unplanned shift in the Centre of Gravity (CG)**, potentially rendering the aircraft uncontrollable, as well as causing **physical damage** to the airframe.

questions.question: If you are flying at FL300 in an air mass that is 15°C warmer than a standard atmosphere, what is the outside temperature likely to be?
questions.explanation: **Standard Temperature at FL300:** $T_{FL300} = \text{SL Temperature} - (\text{Lapse Rate} \times \text{Altitude})$. $T_{FL300} = 15^\circ C - (1.98^\circ C/1,000 \text{ ft} \times 30,000 \text{ ft})$ $T_{FL300} = 15^\circ C - 59.4^\circ C \approx -44.4^\circ C$ (or exactly $-45^\circ C$ using $2^\circ C/1000 \text{ ft}$). **Actual Temperature:** $\text{Standard Temp} + \text{Difference}$ $T_{Actual} = -45^\circ C + 15^\circ C = \mathbf{-30^\circ C}$.

questions.question: What is the frequency range of the airband?
questions.explanation: The civil VHF (Very High Frequency) aviation communications **airband** runs from **118.000 MHz to 136.975 MHz**. This is typically approximated as **108.0 MHz to 137.0 MHz** when including the lower part used for VOR/Localizer navigation aids. The most precise range listed is A, but D is the general band.

questions.question: To achieve the maximum range over the ground with a headwind, a turbojet should fly? (Duplicate of Q2.4)
options: at a speed where the GS to PREQ ratio is greatest
at a speed where the GS to drag ratio is greatest
questions.explanation: Refer to Q2.4. With a **headwind**, a jet should fly **faster** than $\mathbf{V_{\text{L/Dmax}}}$ ($\mathbf{1.32 V_{MD}}$) to maximize range.

questions.question: You are flying IFR in VMC and experience a complete radio failure. What action should you take? (Duplicate of Q3.8)
options: Continue as per last ATC clearance for 20 minutes after which revert to your filed flight plan. Squawk 7500 and land as close as possible to your EAT/ETA. Report arrival to ATC after landing
Continue as per last ATC clearance for 30 minutes after which revert to your filed flight plan. Squawk 7600 and land as close as possible to your EAT/ETA. Report arrival to ATC after landing
Continue as per last ATC clearance for 20 minutes after which revert to your filed flight plan. Squawk 0000 and land as close as possible to your EAT/ETA. Report arrival to ATC after landing
Continue VMC and land at the nearest aerodrome squawking 7600. Report arrival to ATC after landing
questions.explanation: Refer to Q3.8. In IFR and VMC with radio failure, **continue in VMC and land at the nearest suitable aerodrome**, squawking **7600**.

questions.question: When selecting a fuse for an aircraft electrical circuit, what is the governing factor? (Duplicate of Q2.5/Q3.19)
options: the power requirement of the circuit
questions.explanation: Refer to Q2.5. The fuse rating is determined by the expected current draw, which depends on the equipment's **power requirement**.

questions.question: The ILS Localizer operates in which frequency band? (Duplicate of Q1.19)
questions.explanation: Refer to Q1.19. The ILS Localiser operates in the VHF band: **108.0 - 112.0 MHz**.

questions.question: At high altitude, the stall speed (IAS)? (Duplicate of Q3.12)
questions.explanation: Refer to Q3.12. Due to compressibility and Mach effects, the IAS at which the wing stalls effectively **increases** with altitude (the margin between $V_S$ and $V_{MO}/M_{MO}$ narrows).

questions.question: Compared with stalling airspeed (Vs) in a given configuration, the airspeed at which the stick shaker will be triggered is?
questions.explanation: The **stick shaker** is a warning system designed to activate at an angle of attack (AoA) that is safely **above** the stall AoA, providing the pilot with a timely margin to recover. Therefore, the activation airspeed is always **greater than the actual stalling airspeed ($\mathbf{V_S}$)**, typically $\approx 1.05 V_S$ to $1.10 V_S$ (depending on the aircraft).

questions.question: Which of the following are all aerodynamic balances? (Duplicate of Q1.3)
options: Inset hinge, mass balance and spring tab.
Horn balance, balance tab and internal balance.
Horn balance, inset hinge and mass balance.
Internal balance, anti-balance tab and servo tab.
questions.explanation: Refer to Q1.3. **Horn balance, balance tab, and internal balance** are all aerodynamic methods to reduce stick forces.

questions.question: What distance does the DME display? (Duplicate of Q3.13)
options: Line of sight distance in feet
Line of slight distance in NM
questions.explanation: Refer to Q3.13. DME displays **Slant Range in Nautical Miles (NM)**.

questions.question: If an aircraft climbs in the Standard Atmosphere below the Tropopause, at a Constant TAS the Mach Number will?
options: Depend on the rate of change of density with altitude
Decrease because the local speed of sound is decreasing
Increase because the local speed of sound is increasing
Increase because the local speed of sound is decreasing
questions.explanation: **Mach Number** ($M$) is $\frac{\text{TAS}}{\text{LSS}}$ (Local Speed of Sound). In a Standard Atmosphere below the tropopause, temperature decreases with altitude, which causes the **Local Speed of Sound (LSS) to decrease**. If the **TAS is constant** and the LSS decreases, the Mach Number must **increase**.

questions.question: During which stage are downdraughts predominant in a thunderstorm cell?
questions.explanation: A thunderstorm has three stages: 1. **Cumulus (Growth):** Predominantly **updraughts**. 2. **Mature:** Strong **updraughts and downdraughts** co-exist. 3. **Dissipating:** Predominantly **downdraughts** (the precipitation falls, cutting off the fuel of warm rising air).

questions.question: The rigidity of a gyro is improved by?
options: increasing the rpm and concentrating the mass at the hub of the rotor
decreasing the rpm and concentrating the mass on the periphery of the rotor
increasing the rpm and concentrating the mass on the periphery of the rotor
decreasing the rpm and concentrating the mass at the hub of the rotor
questions.explanation: A gyroscope's **rigidity in space** (its ability to resist outside forces) is proportional to its **angular momentum** ($L$). Angular momentum is increased by **increasing the rotor's mass, increasing its rotational speed (RPM)**, and distributing the mass as far as possible from the axis of rotation (**concentrating the mass on the periphery of the rotor**).

questions.question: Which VDF bearing is accurate within 5 degrees?
questions.explanation: VDF (VHF Direction Finder) bearings are classified by their accuracy: * **Class A:** $\pm 2^\circ$ * **Class B:** $\pm 5^\circ$ * **Class C:** $\pm 10^\circ$ * **Class D:** More than $\pm 10^\circ$ (unreliable) Thus, **Class B** is accurate within $5^\circ$.

questions.question: Readability 1 means that the transmission is?
questions.explanation: The Readability scale in communications uses a 1 to 5 rating, where: * **Readability 1:** Unreadable. * Readability 2: Readable now and then. * Readability 3: Readable but with difficulty. * Readability 4: Readable. * Readability 5: Perfectly readable.

questions.question: Which phraseology shall a pilot use if he/she receives an instruction from ATC which he/she cannot carry out?
questions.explanation: The standard ICAO phraseology to communicate that an instruction cannot be executed for any reason is simply **"UNABLE"** (followed by the reason if necessary). This is the mandatory phrase used to deny an ATC clearance or instruction.

questions.question: An aircraft passes overhead a DME station at 12,000 ft above the station. At that time the DME reading will be?
options: FLAG/OFF, the aircraft is within the cone of silence.
questions.explanation: When directly overhead a DME, the ground distance (GD) is zero, and the slant range (SR) equals the aircraft's altitude (A). $A = 12,000 \text{ ft}$. $\text{SR} = 12,000 \text{ ft} / 6,076 \text{ ft/NM} \approx 1.97 \text{ NM}$. The DME reading will be the altitude, which is **approximately 2 NM**.

questions.question: The phrase "take-off" is used by a pilot:
options: Never. It is used only by a ground station
questions.explanation: ICAO phraseology restricts the pilot's use of the word **"take-off"** to only two instances: when **acknowledging the take-off clearance** issued by ATC (e.g., "Cleared for take-off, [Callsign]"), or in a cancellation of that clearance. In all other requests for departure, the word "departure" is used.

questions.question: A pilot approaching an upslope runway:
options: may feel that he is higher than actual. This illusion may cause him to land short of the runway
may feel that he is lower than actual. This illusion may cause him to land further down the runway than intended
may feel that he is lower than actual. This illusion may cause him to fly a steeper than normal approach path
establishes a slower than normal approach speed with the risk of stalling out
questions.explanation: An **upsloping runway** creates a visual illusion where the pilot perceives the aircraft to be **higher than it actually is**. The reaction is to push the nose down to correct for this perceived height, which leads to a lower-than-normal approach path and the risk of **landing short of the runway**.

questions.question: Which of the statements is true concerning squall lines?
options: For severe squall lines a TAF is issued
For severe squall lines a SIGMET is issued
Severe squall lines always move from northwest to southeast
Severe squall lines only occur in the tropics
questions.explanation: A **squall line** is a line of severe thunderstorms, which constitutes a significant weather hazard. ICAO regulations require that such phenomena be reported by the issuance of a **SIGMET** (SIGnificant METeorological Information), not just a routine TAF.

questions.question: When are lifejackets required? (Duplicate of Q3.6)
questions.explanation: Refer to Q3.6. Lifejackets are generally required for flights extending more than **50 NM from the shore**.

questions.question: Main and nose wheel bays are:
options: Different, with the mains being unpressurised and the nose pressurised
questions.explanation: The main and nose landing gear bays are located outside the aircraft's primary pressure vessel. While they may have ventilation, they are considered **unpressurised** compartments and are exposed to the ambient atmospheric pressure and temperature outside the aircraft.

questions.question: Identify runway remaining lighting on centerline lighting systems.
options: Alternate red and white lights from 3,000 feet to 1,000 feet, then red lights to the end.
Alternate red and white lights from 3,000 feet to the end of the runway
Amber lights from 3,000 feet to 1,000 feet, then red lights to the end
Red lights for the last 1,000 feet
questions.explanation: For a runway with centerline lighting, the change in colour indicates remaining distance: * **3000 ft to 1000 ft remaining:** **Alternate red and white lights**. * **Last 1000 ft remaining:** **Red lights only**.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of VHF over HF communications?
options: VHF has longer range than HF at night time
VHF has longer range than HF
VHF range is only restricted by the curvature of the earth
VHF is less affected by atmospheric noise and electrical equipment
questions.explanation: High Frequency (HF) is susceptible to static, lightning, and atmospheric interference, leading to poor voice quality. **VHF (Very High Frequency)** is a line-of-sight signal and is far **less affected by atmospheric noise and electrical equipment**, providing a clear, high-quality signal within its range.

questions.question: What action is required by the pilot of an aircraft station if he/she is unable to establish radio contact with an aeronautical station?
options: Try to establish communication with other aircraft or aeronautical stations
Land at the nearest aerodrome appropriate to the route of flight
questions.explanation: When experiencing difficulty establishing communications (e.g., loss of one station), the pilot's first step is to follow the emergency frequency procedures and attempt to relay the message through **another aircraft or another aeronautical station** (e.g., Flight Information Centre/FIC) before declaring a full radio failure.

questions.question: The rate of climb is approximately equal to?
options: The still air gradient multiplied by the TAS
The angle of climb multiplied by the TAS
The still air gradient divided by the TAS
The angle of climb divided by the TAS
questions.explanation: The **Rate of Climb (RoC)** is approximately equal to the vertical distance climbed per unit of time. It can be calculated as the ratio of excess thrust (power) to weight, or geometrically as the product of the climb **gradient** (angle) and the **True Airspeed (TAS)**: $\mathbf{RoC \approx \text{Climb Gradient} \times \text{TAS}}$.

questions.question: The purpose of the primary stops in a control system is?
options: To set the range of movement of the control surface
To limit control movement to one direction only
To adjust the sensitivity of the controls
To hold the controls in the desired position
questions.explanation: **Primary stops** are physical limitations built into the flight control system (usually in the cockpit or near the primary flight controls) to mechanically **set the maximum range of travel** of the control columns/yokes and, consequently, the control surfaces.

questions.question: Ailerons control which motion?
options: The aileron control is moved to the left and the right aileron moves down and the left one up
The aileron control is moved to the left and the right aileron moves up and the left down
The aileron control is moved to the right and the right elevator goes up and the left one down
The aileron control is moved to the right, the right aileron goes up and the left one down
questions.explanation: **Ailerons** control the **roll** motion. Moving the control (yoke/stick) to the right commands a right roll. This is achieved by raising the aileron on the right wing (reducing lift) and lowering the aileron on the left wing (increasing lift). Thus, moving the control to the right causes the **right aileron to go up and the left one down**.

questions.question: The phrase "say again" means?
options: Repeat the last section of the message
questions.explanation: The standard ICAO phraseology **"SAY AGAIN"** is used to request that the station addressed **repeat the entire transmission** because it was not understood, received, or clearly heard.

questions.question: The best L/D ratio of an aircraft in a given configuration is a value that:
options: Varies depending upon the weight being carried
Remains constant regardless of Indicated Air Speed changes
questions.explanation: The **maximum Lift-to-Drag ratio ($\mathbf{L/D_{\text{max}}}$)** occurs at a specific **Angle of Attack (AoA)**. Since the wing's shape (configuration) is fixed, the AoA for $\mathbf{L/D_{\text{max}}}$ is constant. As $\mathbf{L/D_{\text{max}}}$ is purely a function of AoA, its value **remains constant** for any given configuration, irrespective of weight, altitude, or speed (as long as Mach effects are negligible).

questions.question: How do you know you are in an over taking position with regards to another aircraft at night?
options: You will see a white and a red light
You will see a white and a green light
You will see a white light
You will not see the anti-collision light
questions.explanation: An aircraft's lights include red (left wing), green (right wing), and a **white rear navigation light** (tail or aft-most). To be in an **overtaking position** (coming from behind), the overtaking aircraft can only see the **white tail light** of the aircraft being overtaken. The red and green lights are not visible from the rear.

questions.question: Stringers are used in aircraft fuselage construction:
options: To withstand bending and compressive loads
To withstand tensile and bending loads
To withstand compressive and shear loads
To withstand bending and shear loads
questions.explanation: In a semi-monocoque fuselage, the frames/bulkheads resist pressure and maintain shape, the skin resists shear and pressure, and the **stringers** (longitudinal members) work with the skin to primarily resist **bending and compressive loads** along the length of the fuselage.

questions.question: If temperature remains constant with an increase in altitude there is:
questions.explanation: An **Isothermal Layer** is a layer of the atmosphere where the temperature **remains constant** with increasing altitude (zero lapse rate). An **inversion** is where temperature *increases* with altitude (a negative lapse rate).

questions.question: If an aeroplane lands below its Max Structural Landing Mass, but above its Performance Limited Landing Mass for the arrival airfield: 1) It might not have sufficient runway length to stop safely 2) Tire temperature limits could be exceeded 3) It will increase structural fatigue 4) Physical damage might be suffered as a result of the extra mass 5) A go-around might not be achievable. The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
questions.explanation: The **Performance Limited Landing Mass** is calculated based on runway length, obstacles, and approach climb performance. Exceeding this limit means: 1) **Insufficient runway length to stop** (due to a longer landing distance). 2) **Tire temperature limits** could be exceeded (due to more braking energy/heat). 3) **Increased structural fatigue** (exceeding the load the airframe is *certified* to take based on performance margins). 5) The required **go-around climb gradient** might not be achievable due to the high mass. 4) Physical damage is less certain than fatigue/overheating.

questions.question: If an extra load is loaded into an aircraft the stall speed is likely to? (Duplicate of Q2.20)
options: Change depending on whether the load was placed FWD or AFT of the C of G
questions.explanation: Refer to Q2.20. An increase in aircraft weight will always **increase the stall speed** ($\mathbf{V_S \propto \sqrt{\text{Weight}}}$).

questions.question: The fuel index:
options: Is used to calculate the correct position of the CG due to different locations of the fuel tanks
Is a standard value given by EASA and can be used for different types of aircraft
Is only used for aeroplanes with wing tip tanks
Is the difference between the zero fuel mass index and the DOI
questions.explanation: The fuel index is a number used in the loading graph (or load sheet) calculation. Like any index, it simplifies the weight and balance calculation by providing a factor related to the fuel's moment, thus helping to determine the aircraft's **Centre of Gravity (CG)** position as fuel is added or consumed.

questions.question: When the met observer reports the amount of cloud present at a station, it will be given as:
options: The amount of cloud, in tenths of the sky covered, using the term oktas
The amount of cloud, in quarters of the sky covered, using the term oktas
The amount of cloud, in eighths of the sky covered, using the term oktas
questions.explanation: In aviation meteorology (METAR/TAF), cloud coverage is reported using the term **oktas**, which measures the amount of sky covered in **eighths** (octa = eight). For example, "BKN020" means Broken clouds (5 to 7 oktas) at 2,000 ft.

questions.question: An accumulator in a hydraulic system will:
questions.explanation: The primary function of a hydraulic **accumulator** (a vessel pre-charged with compressed gas/air) is to act as a reservoir to **store fluid under pressure**. This stored energy is then used to supplement the pump during peak demand, provide emergency power, and absorb pressure surges (dampen fluctuations). Since the key is A, we choose the primary role.

questions.question: You are heading 050°(M) and ATC gives you a radar vector to 030°(M). After 7 mins ATC tells you to resume your own navigation. What should you do?
options: Return to you current flight plan route
Continue on a heading of 050 for 30 minutes
Continue on a heading 050 for 15 minutes
Continue on a heading 050 for 7 minutes
questions.explanation: When ATC issues a vector and subsequently instructs the pilot to **"resume own navigation,"** the pilot must immediately revert to the previously cleared flight plan route. The vector only provides temporary guidance for separation; it does not constitute a new permanent route clearance.

questions.question: What approximate rate of descent is required in order to maintain a 3 degree glide path at a groundspeed of 120 kt?
questions.explanation: The approximate Rate of Descent (RoD) required to maintain a standard $3^\circ$ glide path is calculated by the formula: $\mathbf{RoD \approx \text{Groundspeed } ( \text{kt}) \times 5}$. $\text{RoD} = 120 \text{ kt} \times 5 = \mathbf{600 \text{ ft/min}}$.

questions.question: See the figure below (Not provided). You receive this ATC clearance ".....CLEARED TO THE ABC VORTAC. HOLD SOUTH ON THE ONE EIGHT ZERO RADIAL..." What is the recommended procedure to enter the holding pattern?
questions.explanation: Holding instructions specify an **inbound track** (here $180^\circ$ radial, so inbound track is $180^\circ$). The aircraft is "heading $050^\circ$". $050^\circ$ lies in the **Direct Entry Sector** (Sector 3) for a hold with an inbound track of $180^\circ$. Therefore, the recommended entry is **Direct only**.

questions.question: After experiencing two-way radio communications failure en route, when should a pilot begin the descent for the instrument approach?
options: Upon arrival at any initial approach fix for the instrument approach procedure but not before the flight plan ETA as amended by ATC
Upon arrival at the holding fix depicted on the instrument approach procedure at the corrected ETA, plus or minus 3 minutes
At the primary initial approach fix for the instrument approach procedure at the ETA shown on the flight plan or the EFC time, whichever is later
questions.explanation: In the event of IFR radio failure in IMC, the pilot must begin the approach at the most advantageous time to ensure maximum separation from other traffic. The rule states to begin the descent at the holding fix at the latest of the **Expected Approach Time (EAT)** or the **Estimated Time of Arrival (ETA)** filed in the flight plan. Option C is the most accurate ICAO rule; Option A is a simplified, operationally sound interpretation.

questions.question: Which of the following sequences might be encountered when flying into a microburst?
options: Increased headwind, followed by down-draught, followed by increased tailwind on the approach, or following take-off.
Increased headwind, followed by down-draught, followed by increased tailwind on the approach. Increased tailwind, followed by down-draught, followed by increased headwind following take-off.
Increased headwind, followed by down-draught, followed by increased tailwind on take off. Increased tailwind, followed by down-draught, followed by increased headwind on the approach.
Increased tailwind, followed by down-draught, followed by increased headwind on the take-off. Increased headwind, followed by down-draught, followed by increased tailwind on the approach.
questions.explanation: A **microburst** is a strong localized downdraught associated with a thunderstorm. On approach, the aircraft first encounters the air diverging from the core, creating an **increased headwind**, followed by the central **down-draught**, and finally the diverging air on the opposite side, creating a severe **tailwind**. This sequence leads to a dangerous loss of airspeed and climb performance. The same sequence happens in reverse order on a take-off.

questions.question: What is the approximate height of the tropopause during summer over Southern England?
questions.explanation: The tropopause height varies with latitude and season. Over temperate latitudes like Southern England, the tropopause is typically around $30,000 \text{ ft}$ to $36,000 \text{ ft}$ in winter. In the **summer**, the warmer air causes the tropopause to rise significantly, reaching altitudes often between $40,000 \text{ ft}$ and **$46,000 \text{ ft}$**.

questions.explanation: In a TAF (Terminal Aerodrome Forecast), cloud height is reported in hundreds of feet Above Ground Level (AGL). The sequence starts with **SCT015**, which means **SCT** (Scattered, 3-4 oktas) at **015** (1,500 ft AGL). This is the lowest cloud layer forecast. The subsequent BKN020 (2,000 ft) and TEMPO BKN015CB (1,500 ft Cumulonimbus) are either higher or the same, but $1,500 \text{ ft}$ is the lowest value found.

questions.question: In a fuel system, the oil to fuel heat exchanger allows:
options: Fuel cooling so as to prevent vapor creation likely to unprime nozzles
Fuel heating as required whenever fuel filter clogging is detected
Automatic fuel heating by the engine oil so as to prevent icing in fuel filter
Jet engine oil cooling through thermal exchange with fuel flowing from tanks
questions.explanation: In a jet engine, the **oil-to-fuel heat exchanger** serves two purposes: it heats the fuel to prevent freezing and, more critically for the engine, it uses the cooler fuel flowing from the tanks to cool the hot engine oil, transferring the excess heat to the fuel. Thus, its main function for the engine is **jet engine oil cooling**.

questions.question: What effect would a light crosswind have on the wingtip vortices generated by a large aeroplane that has just taken off:
options: The downwind vortex will tend to remain on the runway longer than the upwind vortex.
A crosswind will rapidly dissipate the strength of both vortices.
A crosswind will move both vortices clear of the runway.
The upwind vortex will tend to remain on the runway longer than the downwind vortex.
questions.explanation: Wingtip vortices drift with the wind. A light crosswind will push both vortices laterally across the runway. The **downwind vortex** will move off the runway relatively quickly. The **upwind vortex** is pushed toward the runway centerline but its sinking motion will keep it near the runway until the wind pushes it far enough to dissipate. This means the **upwind vortex will tend to remain on the runway longer** or threaten the parallel runway/taxiway.

questions.question: The signal from pilot to the signalman (marshaller) which means "brakes applied" is:
options: Fist clenched in front of the face then fingers extended
Arms extended horizontally sideways, palms facing downwards
Arms down and crossed in front of the body
questions.explanation: The standard marshalling signal for **Brakes Applied** (Set Brakes) is a single, clear movement: **raise arm and hand, with fingers extended, horizontally in front of the face, then clench fist**. The reverse (fist clenched then fingers extended) means **Brakes Off**. Option A is correct for Brakes Applied.

questions.question: The main purpose of leading edge flaps/slats is:
options: To give a more cambered section for high-speed flight
To increase wing camber, and prevent separation of the airflow when trailing edge flaps are lowered
To increase the wing area for take-off and landing
To act as an airbrake for rapid deceleration
questions.explanation: The primary function of **leading edge devices (slats/flaps)** is to **control the boundary layer/airflow** over the upper wing surface, particularly at high angles of attack. They prevent premature airflow **separation** (which causes stall) when the high-lift trailing edge flaps are extended, thus significantly increasing the maximum lift coefficient ($\mathbf{C_{Lmax}}$).

questions.question: In an aeroplane utilising a constant frequency AC power supply, DC power is obtained from a:
questions.explanation: A modern aircraft uses **AC (Alternating Current)** for its primary power (usually $115 \text{V}, 400 \text{Hz}$). However, many avionic systems require **DC (Direct Current)** power. This DC power is obtained by stepping down the AC voltage and converting it to DC using a **Transformer Rectifier Unit (TRU)**.

questions.question: The actual zero fuel weight is:
options: The aircraft basic operation weight + payload. And must not exceed the maximum design zero fuel weight
The aircraft basic operation weight + payload. And must not exceed the maximum design take off weight
The aircraft basic operating weight + trip fuel
The maximum landing weight plus the trip fuel
questions.explanation: The **Actual Zero Fuel Weight (ZFW)** is defined as the aircraft's **Basic Operating Weight (BOW)** plus the total **Payload** (passengers, baggage, and cargo). This calculated actual weight must not exceed the structural limit known as the **Maximum Zero Fuel Weight (MZFW)**.

questions.question: What is correct about Fly-by / Fly-over waypoints and turns?
options: A fly-by waypoint is a waypoint which requires turn anticipation to allow tangential interception of the next segment of a route or procedure
A turn via a fly-over waypoint is always shorter than a turn via a fly-by waypoint
A fly-by waypoint is a waypoint at which a turn is initiated in order to join the next segment of a route or procedure
A fly-over waypoint is a waypoint which requires turn anticipation to allow tangential interception of the next segment of a route or procedure
questions.explanation: A **Fly-by** waypoint is used when the turn is to be started **before** the waypoint. The Flight Management System (FMS) calculates **turn anticipation** to allow the aircraft to smoothly roll out onto the tangent of the next segment. A **Fly-over** waypoint requires the aircraft to actually pass **directly over** the point before the turn is initiated.

questions.question: On a summer day, the following observations are made in Zurich: ... (METAR sequence describing weather clearing after TSRA)... You conclude, that... (Figure needed for full context)

The clearing weather is the result of the high-pressure system prevailing behind the front.

questions.question: According to ICAO Doc 8168, the Transition Level:
options: Shall be the lowest flight level available for use above the transition altitude that has been established
Is published in the approach chart(s) concerned
Shall normally be a specified altitude AMSL in the vicinity of an aerodrome
Shall be the highest available flight level below the transition altitude that has been established
questions.explanation: The **Transition Altitude (TA)** is the level at which to change from QNH to QNE (standard pressure setting). The **Transition Level (TL)** is the lowest Flight Level available for use **above** the Transition Altitude. The separation between TA and TL ensures that no altitude and no flight level overlap, providing vertical separation.

questions.question: The vertical position of an aircraft at or below the transition altitude will be reported:
questions.explanation: In the vicinity of an aerodrome, the vertical position of an aircraft operating at or **below the Transition Altitude (TA)** must be referenced to a QNH setting and reported as **Altitude** (distance above Mean Sea Level/MSL). Above the Transition Level, it is reported as a Flight Level (referenced to 1013.25 hPa).

questions.question: A particular instrument departure procedure requires a minimum climb rate of 210 feet per NM to 8,000 feet. If you climb with a ground speed of 140 knots, what is the rate of climb required in feet per minute?
questions.explanation: The required **Rate of Climb (RoC)** is calculated by converting the distance-based gradient to a time-based rate using Groundspeed (GS). $\mathbf{RoC \text{ (ft/min)}} = \text{Gradient } (\text{ft/NM}) \times \text{GS } (\text{NM/min})$. $\mathbf{RoC} = 210 \text{ ft/NM} \times (140/60) \text{ NM/min} = 210 \times 2.333 \approx \mathbf{490 \text{ ft/min}}$.

questions.explanation: For the ILS **Localiser** signal: * The $\mathbf{90 \text{ Hz}}$ signal predominates to the **Left** of the centerline. * The $\mathbf{150 \text{ Hz}}$ signal predominates to the **Right** of the centerline. When the signal depths of modulation (DDM) are equal, the aircraft is on the centreline.

questions.question: When climbing at a constant mach number below the tropopause through an inversion:
options: The CAS will decrease and the TAS will increase
The CAS will increase and the TAS will decrease
The CAS and TAS will both increase
The CAS and TAS will both decrease
questions.explanation: * **Climb:** Density ($\rho$) decreases. * **Inversion:** Temperature (T) increases. * **Constant Mach (M):** $M = \text{TAS} / \text{LSS}$. Since T increases, LSS ($\mathbf{\propto \sqrt{T}}$) increases. To keep M constant, **TAS must increase** (TAS $\propto$ LSS). * **CAS:** Since TAS increases and $\rho$ decreases, the net effect on CAS is complex, but the rise in temperature is the dominant factor in an inversion at constant Mach, resulting in a **decrease in CAS** to maintain the same Mach Number.
