questions.question: 1. When refuelling is being conducted with passengers embarking or disembarking:
options: refuelling is strictly prohibited whilst passengers are embarking/ disembarking
all flight crew must be on board
communications shall be maintained by ground crew and qualified crew on board
the stairs shall be fully extended
questions.explanation: During refuelling with passengers on board or embarking/disembarking, $\mathbf{two} \mathbf{way} \mathbf{communication}$ must be maintained between the ground crew supervising the fuelling and qualified flight or cabin crew on board to coordinate in case of an emergency.

questions.question: 2. What must be ensured with respect to navigation equipment?
options: The failure of one piece does not affect another
All navigation equipment must be serviceable at the start of flight
All equipment must conform to ICAO specifications
If one piece of equipment fails there must be a spare available
questions.explanation: Navigation systems are generally required to be $\mathbf{independent}$ of one another to ensure that the failure of one component (e.g., a power supply) does not result in the loss of all navigation capability.

questions.question: 3. Supplemental oxygen is used to:
options: provide oxygen to passengers who might require it, following decompression
provide oxygen to passengers following decompression if the cabin altitude exceeds 10000 ft
provide oxygen to flight crew following decompression
augment first aid oxygen following decompression
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{passenger} \mathbf{supplemental} \mathbf{oxygen} \mathbf{system}$ is mandated to provide oxygen to passengers in the event of decompression or other incidents where the cabin altitude exceeds $10,000 \text{ ft}$ (specifically $10,000 \text{ ft}$ for more than $30 \text{ minutes}$ or $13,000 \text{ ft}$ at any time).

questions.question: 4. Who is responsible for checking the quantity and security of the cargo on board?
options: The mechanic on board, or in his absence the co-pilot
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Pilot} \mathbf{in} \mathbf{Command} \text{ (Captain)}$ is ultimately responsible for the safe operation of the aircraft, which includes ensuring the aircraft is correctly $\mathbf{loaded}$, including the quantity, distribution, and $\mathbf{security} \mathbf{ of} \mathbf{all} \mathbf{cargo}$.

questions.question: 5. Who is the operator to provide an operations manual for?
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Operations} \mathbf{Manual} \text{ (OM)}$ must contain all instructions and information necessary for $\mathbf{operational} \mathbf{personnel}$ to perform their duties. This generally covers $\mathbf{all} \mathbf{personnel}$ whose duties affect the safety of the flight operation.

questions.question: 6. Information concerning evacuation procedures can be found in the:
questions.explanation: Evacuation and emergency procedures are operational directives contained in the $\mathbf{Operations} \mathbf{Manual} \text{ (OM)}$ (typically in Part $\text{B}$ or $\text{C}$ - Operating Procedures and Non-routine Procedures).

questions.question: 7. To act as co-pilot for take-off or landing you must have:
options: acted as $\text{PIC} \text{ or} \text{ co-pilot} \text{ on} \text{ type} \text{ in} \text{ the} \text{ last} \text{ } 90 \text{ days}$
acted as $\text{PIC} \text{ or} \text{ co-pilot} \text{ on} \text{ type} \text{ in} \text{ the} \text{ last} \text{ } 30 \text{ days}$
acted as $\text{PIC} \text{ or} \text{ co-pilot} \text{ on} \text{ type} \text{ in} \text{ the} \text{ last} \text{ } 60 \text{ days}$
been at the controls for landing in the same type recently
questions.explanation: The most common recent experience requirement for a pilot to conduct take-offs and landings is $\mathbf{3} \mathbf{take} \text{-}\mathbf{offs} \mathbf{and} \mathbf{landings}$ within the previous $\mathbf{90} \mathbf{days}$. Option $\text{C}$ references a $\mathbf{60} \mathbf{day}$ period which is also a common regulatory period for specific checks, but for $3 \text{ in } 90 \text{ days}$ is the primary currency. However, based on the provided options, $\text{C}$ is often a requirement from the $\text{OM}$ for line checks or operator-specific rules. Assuming the question intended to ask for $3 \text{ in } 90 \text{ days}$, the best option is $\text{A}s time period combined with the action, but $\text{C}$ is a strong operator-defined possibility. Given the ambiguity and the standard $90 \text{ days}$ rule, $\text{A}$ is the closest general regulatory match if the $60 \text{ days}$ in $\text{C}$ is not the intended correct period. We will use the $\mathbf{90} \mathbf{day} \text{ period}$ as per $\text{FAR}/\text{EASA}$ commonality. Let's use $\mathbf{A}$ as the currency is usually tied to $\mathbf{90} \mathbf{days}$ (See Q8 and Q14 which confirm a $\text{90 days}$ focus). **Revisiting Q7 & Q8/Q14**: Given that Q8 and Q14 point to $90 \text{ days}$, Option A is the most plausible general regulatory period for currency.

questions.question: 8. What is the co-pilot currency requirement?
options: $3 \text{ take-offs} \text{ and} \text{ landings} \text{ in} \text{ the} \text{ last} \text{ } 60 \text{ days}$
At the controls for $3 \text{ take-offs} \text{ and} \text{ landings} \text{ within} \text{ the} \text{ previous} \text{ } 90 \text{ days}$
$3 \text{ take-offs} \text{ and} \text{ landings} \text{ in} \text{ the} \text{ previous} \text{ } 90 \text{ days}$
questions.explanation: A pilot (including co-pilot) must have carried out at least $\mathbf{3} \mathbf{take} \text{-}\mathbf{offs} \mathbf{and} \mathbf{landings}$ as pilot flying or pilot monitoring in the last $\mathbf{90} \mathbf{days}$ in the class/type or a $\text{FSTD}$ to act as $\text{PIC}$ or $\text{Co-pilot}$. $\text{C}$ emphasizes being $\mathbf{at} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{controls}$ which aligns with the pilot flying role required for this currency.

questions.question: 9. One shall not initiate any flight made in accordance with instrument flight rules unless the available information indicates that the conditions at the aerodrome of intended destination and destination alternate (if one is required) are, at the predicted time of:
options: take-off equal to or better than the minimum conditions required for aerodrome use
arrival, and for a reasonable time before and after such a predicted time, equal to minimum conditions required for aerodrome use
arrival equal to or better than the minimum conditions required for aerodrome use
arrival better than the minimum conditions required for aerodrome use
questions.explanation: For $\text{IFR}$ flights, weather at the destination and alternate must be $\mathbf{equal} \mathbf{to} \mathbf{or} \mathbf{better} \mathbf{than} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{minimum}$ conditions required for aerodrome use for a period $\mathbf{before} \mathbf{and} \mathbf{after} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{Estimated} \mathbf{Time} \mathbf{ of} \mathbf{Arrival} \text{ (ETA)}$.

questions.question: 10. Where is the Minimum Equipment List?
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Minimum} \mathbf{Equipment} \mathbf{List} \text{ (MEL)}$ is an operational document that forms part of the $\mathbf{Operations} \mathbf{Manual} \text{ (OM)}$ (usually Part $\text{A}$ or $\text{B}$), or is carried as a separate document, but is formally part of the operational system described in the $\text{OM}$.

questions.question: 11. $\text{FDR}$s must keep data and parameters for at least the last:
questions.explanation: $\text{ICAO}$ and $\text{EASA}$ regulations specify that the flight data recorder ($\mathbf{FDR}$) must retain the data recorded during at least the $\mathbf{last} \mathbf{10} \mathbf{hours} \mathbf{ of} \mathbf{operation}$ for smaller aircraft, and $25 \text{ hours}$ for larger or newer aircraft. $10 \text{ hours}$ is the minimum standard listed.

questions.question: 12. The period of validity for an operator's certificate is:
questions.explanation: Under current EASA regulations, an $\mathbf{Air} \mathbf{Operator} \mathbf{Certificate} \text{ (AOC)}$ is issued for an $\mathbf{indefinite} \mathbf{duration}$ (i.e., it does not expire) provided the holder remains compliant with the applicable requirements. It is subject to continuous safety oversight.

questions.question: 13. When are flight crew allowed to leave their stations?
options: In the performance of their duties
At any time specified by the $\text{OM}$
Only when the captain allows it
questions.explanation: Flight crew members must remain at their station unless $\mathbf{necessary} \mathbf{for} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{performance} \mathbf{of} \mathbf{their} \mathbf{duties}$ or for physiological needs, and relief is provided if necessary to maintain minimum crew requirements.

questions.question: 14. The recent experience conditions of a captain assigned to a flight on an aircraft by an operator must not be less than:
options: $6 \text{ take-offs} \text{ and} \text{ } 6 \text{ landings} \text{ as} \text{ pilot} \text{ in} \text{ command} \text{ on} \text{ this} \text{ type} \text{ of} \text{ aircraft} \text{ during} \text{ the} \text{ last} \text{ } 90 \text{ days}$

$3 \text{ take-offs} \text{ and} \text{ } 3 \text{ landings} \text{ as} \text{ pilot} \text{ in} \text{ command} \text{ on} \text{ this} \text{ type} \text{ of} \text{ aircraft} \text{ during} \text{ the} \text{ last} \text{ } 6 \text{ months}$

$6 \text{ take-offs} \text{ and} \text{ } 6 \text{ landings} \text{ as} \text{ pilot} \text{ in} \text{ command} \text{ on} \text{ this} \text{ type} \text{ of} \text{ aircraft} \text{ during} \text{ the} \text{ last} \text{ } 6 \text{ months}$

$3 \text{ take-offs} \text{ and} \text{ } 3 \text{ landings} \text{ as} \text{ pilot} \text{ in} \text{ command} \text{ on} \text{ this} \text{ type} \text{ of} \text{ aircraft} \text{ during} \text{ the} \text{ last} \text{ } 90 \text{ days}$
questions.explanation: To maintain pilot currency (PBN), a pilot must have completed $\mathbf{3} \mathbf{take} \text{-}\mathbf{offs} \mathbf{and} \mathbf{3} \mathbf{landings}$ within the preceding $\mathbf{90} \mathbf{days}$ in the aircraft type or a $\text{FSTD}$ to act as a pilot (including $\text{PIC}$).

questions.question: 15. The Minimum Equipment List ($\text{MEL}$) is established by the:
options: aeronautical Authority the airline operator depends on
Civil Aviation Authority of the European states
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{airline} \mathbf{operator}$ $\mathbf{establishes} \text{ (writes} \text{ and} \text{ proposes)}$ the $\mathbf{MEL}$, tailoring it from the manufacturer's $\text{MMEL} \text{ (Master} \text{ Minimum} \text{ Equipment} \text{ List)}$. It is then $\mathbf{approved} \mathbf{by} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{Authority}$.

questions.question: 16. When are life jackets required?
questions.explanation: Life jackets are required when operating over water $\mathbf{beyond} \mathbf{50} \mathbf{NM} \mathbf{from} \mathbf{shore}$, or a distance corresponding to $\mathbf{30} \mathbf{minutes}$ flying time at normal cruise speed.

questions.question: 17. Aeroplanes with a take-off mass greater than $5700 \text{ kg} \text{ shall} \text{ be} \text{ fitted} \text{ with} \text{ an} \text{ independent} \text{ automatically} \text{ operated} \text{ emergency} \text{ power} \text{ supply} \text{ to} \text{ operate} \text{ and} \text{ illuminate} \text{ the} \text{ artificial} \text{ horizon} \text{ for}:$
questions.explanation: For aircraft above this mass threshold, an independent emergency power source must be available to power and illuminate the attitude indicator (artificial horizon) for at least $\mathbf{30} \mathbf{minutes}$ following a main power failure.

questions.question: 18. When do you not need a destination alternate aerodrome?
options: If there is a reasonable certainty that at the $\text{ETA} \text{ at} \text{ the} \text{ destination} \text{ aerodrome} \text{ and} \text{ a} \text{ reasonable} \text{ time} \text{ before} \text{ and} \text{ after} \text{ you} \text{ can} \text{ expect} \text{ VMC}$
If the flight time is more than $6 \text{ hours}$
If the flight time is less than $1 \text{ hour}$
If your operator deems the weather to be suitable for a visual landing
questions.explanation: A destination alternate is $\mathbf{not} \mathbf{required}$ if the weather at the destination (for the period of the $\text{ETA} \pm$ reasonable time) indicates conditions that permit a $\mathbf{visual} \mathbf{approach} \mathbf{and} \mathbf{landing}$.

questions.question: 19. A piece of equipment on your public transport aeroplane fails while you are still parked. The reference document you use to decide on the procedure to follow is the:
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Minimum} \mathbf{Equipment} \mathbf{List} \text{ (MEL)}$ is the $\mathbf{master} \mathbf{document}$ used by the pilot to determine if an aircraft can be $\mathbf{dispatched}$ with inoperative equipment.

questions.question: 20. Where is the general information and policy on fuel located?
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Operations} \mathbf{Manual} \mathbf{Part} \mathbf{A} \text{ (OM} \mathbf{A})$ contains $\mathbf{general} \mathbf{operating} \mathbf{policies}$, including general principles and policy on $\mathbf{fuel} \mathbf{planning}$ and management.

questions.question: 1. What is the requirement for the carriage of life rafts?
options: 60 mins flying time at the one engine out cruise speed
questions.explanation: Life rafts are required for $\mathbf{Extended} \mathbf{Overwater} \mathbf{Operations}$, defined as flying further than $\mathbf{120} \mathbf{minutes} \mathbf{at} \mathbf{cruising} \mathbf{speed}$ or $\mathbf{400} \mathbf{NM}$ (depending on the regulation), $\mathbf{whichever} \mathbf{is} \mathbf{less}$, from land suitable for an emergency landing.

questions.question: 2. Who compiles the $\text{MEL} \text{ and} \text{ where} \text{ does} \text{ it} \text{ go}$?
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Minimum} \mathbf{Equipment} \mathbf{List} \text{ (MEL)}$ is $\mathbf{compiled} \mathbf{by} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{operator}$ (based on the manufacturer's Master $\text{MMEL}$) and is an integral part of the $\mathbf{Operations} \mathbf{Manual} \text{ (OM)}$.

questions.question: 3. Following an indication of an unserviceability whilst taxiing to the holding point, what do you consult first?
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Minimum} \mathbf{Equipment} \mathbf{List} \text{ (MEL)}$ is the document consulted by the flight crew to determine if an aircraft can $\mathbf{commence}$ or $\mathbf{continue}$ a flight with specific equipment $\mathbf{unserviceable}$.

questions.question: 4. On board a $\mathbf{pressurized} \mathbf{aircraft}$, a flight shall be undertaken only if the aircraft is provided with an oxygen reserve enabling all the crew members to be supplied with oxygen for any period of flight above a cabin altitude of:
questions.explanation: For $\mathbf{crew} \mathbf{supplemental} \mathbf{oxygen} \mathbf{reserve}$, it must be sufficient for the entire flight time when the cabin altitude exceeds $\mathbf{13,000} \mathbf{ft}$.

questions.question: 5. How often should pilot proficiency checks be performed?
options: No less than $6 \text{ months} \text{ between} \text{ checks}$
$3 \text{ checks} \text{ within} \text{ the} \text{ year} \text{ with} \text{ no} \text{ less} \text{ than} \text{ } 4 \text{ months} \text{ between} \text{ checks}$
$2 \text{ within} \text{ a} \text{ year}, \text{ more} \text{ than} \text{ } 4 \text{ months} \text{ between} \text{ checks}$
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Pilot} \mathbf{Proficiency} \mathbf{Check} \text{ (PPC)}$ is typically required every $\mathbf{6} \mathbf{months}$. To maintain continuous validity for $\mathbf{12} \mathbf{months}$, $\mathbf{two} \mathbf{checks}$ must be completed within a $\mathbf{year}$, with the $\mathbf{interval} \mathbf{between} \mathbf{them} \mathbf{being} \mathbf{more} \mathbf{than} \mathbf{4} \mathbf{months}$ to ensure checks are reasonably distributed.

questions.question: 6. Who is responsible for ensuring that the aeroplane is airworthy prior to flight?
questions.explanation: While the operator is responsible for providing an airworthy aircraft, the $\mathbf{Captain} \text{ (Pilot} \mathbf{in} \mathbf{Command)}$ has the $\mathbf{final} \mathbf{responsibility}$ and authority to determine if the aircraft is in a $\mathbf{safe} \mathbf{condition} \mathbf{for} \mathbf{flight}$.

questions.question: 7. What is the requirement regarding the carriage of a $\text{CVR}$ for aircraft registered $\mathbf{before} \mathbf{April} \mathbf{1998}$?
options: Record for the duration of the flight
Record the last $25 \text{ hours} \text{ of} \text{ operation}$
Record the last $48 \text{ hours} \text{ of} \text{ flight}$
questions.explanation: Older regulations and aircraft registered before the rule change typically required the $\mathbf{Cockpit} \mathbf{Voice} \mathbf{Recorder} \text{ (CVR)}$ to record a minimum of the $\mathbf{last} \mathbf{30} \mathbf{minutes}$ of cockpit audio. Modern regulations require $2 \text{ hours}$ ($120 \text{ minutes}$).

questions.question: 8. Who is to ensure safe handling of flights?
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Aircraft} \mathbf{Operator}$ holds the primary responsibility for the $\mathbf{safety}$ and $\mathbf{security}$ of its flight operations.

questions.question: 9. The crew members must use their seatbelts:
options: only during take-off and landing and $\mathbf{whenever} \mathbf{necessary} \mathbf{by} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{commander} \mathbf{in} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{interest} \mathbf{of} \mathbf{safety}$
questions.explanation: Regulations mandate the use of seatbelts during $\mathbf{take} \text{-}\mathbf{off} \mathbf{and} \mathbf{landing}$. The $\mathbf{Commander}$ can also require their use at any other time (e.g., during turbulence).

questions.question: 10. An $\text{NDB} \text{ approach} \text{ has} \text{ an} \text{ MDH} \text{ of} \text{ } 360 \text{ ft} \text{ and} \text{ a} \text{ required} \text{ RVR} \text{ of} \text{ } 1500 \text{ m}$. $\text{Reported} \text{ $\text{Met}$ vis} \text{ is} \text{ } 2500 \text{ m}$. When can you start an approach?
options: When the cloud base is above the system minimum
When the cloud base is above $36 \text{ ft}$
When the cloud base report is received
questions.explanation: The decision to $\mathbf{commence} \mathbf{an} \mathbf{instrument} \mathbf{approach}$ is based $\mathbf{only} \mathbf{on} \mathbf{visibility}$ or $\mathbf{RVR}$. Since the reported visibility ($2500 \text{ m}$) is $\mathbf{above} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{required} \mathbf{minima} \text{ ($1500 \text{ m}$)}$, the approach can be started $\mathbf{regardless} \mathbf{of} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{reported} \mathbf{cloud} \mathbf{base}$. Cloud base is only used to determine if the runway environment can be $\mathbf{visually} \mathbf{acquired}$ at $\mathbf{MDH}$.

questions.question: 11. The $\text{MEL} \text{ is} \text{ drawn} \text{ up} \text{ by} \text{ the}:$
options: operator and may be more restrictive than the $\text{MMEL}$
operator and may be less restrictive than the $\text{MMEL}$
manufacturer and may be more restrictive than the $\text{MMEL}$
manufacturer and may be less restrictive than the $\text{MMEL}$
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{MEL}$ is drawn up by the $\mathbf{operator}$ based on the $\mathbf{MMEL} \text{ (Master} \mathbf{MEL} \text{ by} \mathbf{manufacturer)}$ and $\mathbf{may} \mathbf{be} \mathbf{more} \mathbf{restrictive}$ to suit their operation, but $\mathbf{never} \mathbf{less} \mathbf{restrictive}$.

questions.question: 12. On an $\text{ILS}$, you are told that the weather has $\mathbf{dropped} \mathbf{below} \mathbf{company} \mathbf{minima}$. When must you abort the approach?
options: Start of the glide slope descent
questions.explanation: The decision to $\mathbf{continue} \mathbf{or} \mathbf{abort} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{approach}$ due to RVR/Visibility is made at the $\mathbf{Outer} \mathbf{Marker} \text{ (or} \mathbf{FAF} \text{ or} \mathbf{equivalent} \mathbf{position)}$. If the weather deteriorates $\mathbf{after} \mathbf{this} \mathbf{point}$, the approach can continue to $\mathbf{DH}/\mathbf{MDA}$.

questions.question: 13. Which communications systems must be carried for $\mathbf{IFR} \mathbf{flights}$?
options: $2 \text{ independent} \text{ VHF} \text{ boxes} \text{ or} \text{ one} \text{ VHF} \text{ and} \text{ one} \text{ HF}$
One $\text{VHF} \text{ box} \text{ and} \text{ one} \text{ HF} \text{ box}$
questions.explanation: For $\mathbf{IFR} \mathbf{flights} \mathbf{in} \mathbf{controlled} \mathbf{airspace}$, aircraft must be equipped with $\mathbf{two} \mathbf{independent} \mathbf{VHF} \mathbf{communication} \mathbf{systems}$ to ensure redundancy. $\text{HF}$ is only required for long overwater or remote flights.

questions.question: 14. Who provides the operations personnel with the $\text{OM} \text{ and} \text{ the} \text{ amendments} \text{ to} \text{ keep} \text{ it} \text{ up} \text{ to} \text{ date}$?
options: $\text{ATS} \text{ authority} \text{ of} \text{ the} \text{ State} \text{ of} \text{ Registry}$
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Aircraft} \mathbf{Operator}$ is responsible for the overall management of the $\mathbf{Operations} \mathbf{Manual} \text{ (OM)}$, including its production, distribution, and ensuring all amendments are provided to the relevant personnel.

questions.question: 15. What is the oxygen requirement for the crew and $\mathbf{100\%} \mathbf{of} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{passengers} \mathbf{in} \mathbf{an} \mathbf{unpressurized} \mathbf{aircraft}$?
questions.explanation: In an $\mathbf{unpressurized} \mathbf{aircraft}$, $\mathbf{all} \mathbf{occupants}$ must be supplied with oxygen for the entire flight time $\mathbf{above} \mathbf{13,000} \mathbf{ft} \text{ MSL}$.

questions.question: 16. A modern aircraft must be provided with a flight data recorder when its certified $\text{MTOM} \text{ is} \text{ greater} \text{ than}:$
questions.explanation: $\text{ICAO}$ and EASA regulations specify that most multi-engine turbine aeroplanes used in commercial air transport operations, and all aeroplanes with an $\mathbf{MTOM}$ $\mathbf{greater} \mathbf{than} \mathbf{5,700} \mathbf{kg}$, must be equipped with a $\mathbf{Flight} \mathbf{Data} \mathbf{Recorder} \text{ (FDR)}$.

questions.question: 17. What skills constitute pilot proficiency checks?
options: The ability to conform with set procedures
questions.explanation: A $\mathbf{PPC}$ is a comprehensive evaluation covering the pilot's $\mathbf{instrument} \mathbf{flying} \text{ (IFR)}$ ability, $\mathbf{handling} \mathbf{skills} \text{ (technique)}$, and ability to safely execute $\mathbf{emergency} \mathbf{and} \mathbf{abnormal} \mathbf{procedures}$.

questions.question: 18. The $\text{OPS} \mathbf{document}$ is based on:
questions.explanation: International commercial air transport operations are founded on the standards and recommended practices contained in $\mathbf{ICAO} \mathbf{Annex} \mathbf{6} \text{ (Operation} \mathbf{ of} \mathbf{Aircraft)}$, which national and regional regulations (like $\text{EASA} \text{ OPS}$) are derived from.

questions.question: 19. Above what altitude are $\mathbf{quick} \text{-}\mathbf{donning} \mathbf{masks}$ required?
questions.explanation: $\mathbf{Quick} \text{-}\mathbf{donning} \mathbf{oxygen} \mathbf{masks}$ are required for flight crew in pressurized aircraft capable of operating $\mathbf{above} \mathbf{Flight} \mathbf{Level} \mathbf{250} \text{ ($25,000} \mathbf{ft})$ to ensure immediate protection in case of rapid decompression.

questions.question: 20. Destination alternate for a $\mathbf{turbojet} \text{ -} \mathbf{what} \mathbf{is} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{required} \mathbf{fuel} \mathbf{overhead}$?
options: $2 \text{ hours} \text{ at} \text{ } 1500 \text{ ft} \text{ in} \text{ standard} \text{ conditions}$
questions.explanation: The fuel required overhead the $\mathbf{destination} \mathbf{alternate}$ aerodrome is the $\mathbf{Final} \mathbf{Reserve} \mathbf{Fuel} \text{ (FRF)}$. For a $\mathbf{turbine} \mathbf{aeroplane}$, this is the amount required to $\mathbf{hold} \mathbf{for} \mathbf{30} \mathbf{minutes}$ at $\mathbf{1,500} \mathbf{ft} \text{ (above} \text{ the} \text{ aerodrome} \text{ elevation)}$ at $\mathbf{holding} \mathbf{speed} \mathbf{in} \mathbf{standard} \mathbf{conditions}$.

questions.question: 1. At the alternate aerodrome, the commander of a turbojet engine aeroplane should have a fuel quantity ($\mathbf{final} \mathbf{reserve}$) sufficient for flying during:
options: 30 minutes at holding flight speed at 1500 ft
45 minutes at holding flight speed at 1500 ft
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Final} \mathbf{Reserve} \mathbf{Fuel} \text{ (FRF)}$ for a turbine aeroplane is the amount of fuel required to $\mathbf{hold} \mathbf{for} \mathbf{30} \mathbf{minutes}$ at $\mathbf{1,500} \mathbf{ft}$ above the aerodrome elevation in standard conditions.

questions.question: 2. Where is $\mathbf{permanent} \mathbf{approval}$ for the carriage of $\mathbf{dangerous} \mathbf{goods}$ given?
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Air} \mathbf{Operator}'\mathbf{s} \mathbf{Certificate} \text{ (AOC)}$ specifies the $\mathbf{scope}$ and $\mathbf{conditions}$ of the operator's commercial air transport operations, including the authority to carry $\mathbf{Dangerous} \mathbf{Goods}$.

questions.question: 3. The $\mathbf{Minimum} \mathbf{Equipment} \mathbf{List} \text{ (MEL)}$ gives the equipment which can be inoperative when undertaking a flight... This list is prepared by:
options: the manufacturer, and it is included in the Operations Manual
the manufacturer, and it is included in the Aircraft Flight Manual
the operator, and it is included in the Aircraft Flight Manual
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{operator}$ prepares the $\mathbf{MEL}$ (based on the manufacturer's $\text{MMEL}$), and it is an $\mathbf{approved} \mathbf{part}$ of the $\mathbf{Operations} \mathbf{Manual} \text{ (OM)}$.

questions.question: 4. Which documents must be carried on every flight? 1. $\text{C}$ of $\text{A}$ 2. $\text{C}$ of $\text{R}$ 3. Noise Certificate 4. $\text{AOC}$ 5. Aircraft Radio Licence 6. Insurance Certificate
questions.explanation: For commercial air transport, $\mathbf{all} \mathbf{six}$ documents (Certificate of Airworthiness, Certificate of Registration, Noise Certificate, Air Operator's Certificate/relevant part, Aircraft Radio Station Licence, and Insurance/Liability Certificate) are generally required to be carried on every flight.

questions.question: 5. From the flight deck you observe an aeroplane in the forward $\mathbf{left} \mathbf{position} \mathbf{on} \mathbf{an} \mathbf{opposite} \mathbf{parallel} \mathbf{track}$. What $\mathbf{Nav} \mathbf{light}$ will be observed?
questions.explanation: If an aircraft is on an $\mathbf{opposite} \mathbf{track}$ (coming towards you) and is on your $\mathbf{left}$, you will see its $\mathbf{red}$ (port/left wing) navigation light.

questions.question: 6. In determining Aerodrome Operating Minima, what of the following needs to be considered? 1. Crew composition 2. Ability to communicate/receive meteorological information 3. Significant obstacles in the missed approach area 4. Dimensions and characteristics of the runway 5. Navigation equipment in the aeroplane
questions.explanation: $\mathbf{Aerodrome} \mathbf{Operating} \mathbf{Minima}$ calculation involves factors related to the $\mathbf{aerodrome}$ itself (2, 3, 4) and the $\mathbf{aircraft}'\mathbf{s} \mathbf{capability}$ (5). $\mathbf{Crew} \mathbf{composition} \text{ (1)}$ is addressed by $\mathbf{pilot} \mathbf{currency}$ and $\mathbf{training} \mathbf{requirements}$, not the minima calculation for the aerodrome.

questions.question: 7. The $\mathbf{MMEL}$ is:
options: compiled by the manufacturer and approved by the operator
compiled by the operator and approved by the state
compiled by the operator and approved by the state of design or state of the manufacturer
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Master} \mathbf{Minimum} \mathbf{Equipment} \mathbf{List} \text{ (MMEL)}$ is the master document, created by the $\mathbf{manufacturer}$ and $\mathbf{approved}$ by their $\mathbf{State} \mathbf{of} \mathbf{Design} \mathbf{Authority}$.

questions.question: 8. The $\mathbf{Operations} \mathbf{Manual} \text{ (OM)}$ must be approved by the Authority of the:
options: no such book is required to be approved by an authority
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Authority} \mathbf{that} \mathbf{issues} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{AOC}$ (the State of the $\mathbf{Operator}$) is responsible for approving the $\mathbf{Operations} \mathbf{Manual}$.

questions.question: 9. During a flight, the captain is informed that a passenger is using a $\mathbf{portable} \mathbf{electronic} \mathbf{device}$, which is $\mathbf{adversely} \mathbf{affecting} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{aircraft}'\mathbf{s} \mathbf{electrical} \mathbf{avionics}$. The captain must:
options: allow the device to be used at take-off and landing
allow the device to be used from take-off to landing
allow the device to be used for certain exceptions
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Pilot} \mathbf{in} \mathbf{Command} \text{ (Captain)}$ has the $\mathbf{ultimate} \mathbf{authority}$ and responsibility for the safety of the flight and $\mathbf{must} \mathbf{prohibit} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{use}$ of any device that interferes with the aircraft's systems.

questions.question: 10. Who $\mathbf{issues} \mathbf{and} \mathbf{updates} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{MEL}$?
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{operator}$ is responsible for $\mathbf{issuing}$ the $\text{MEL}$ as part of their $\text{OM}$ and for $\mathbf{maintaining} \mathbf{it}$ with all necessary updates and revisions.

questions.question: 11. What manuals are to be carried?
options: Company instructions for all flight crew
All those specified in the Certificate of Airworthiness
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Aircraft} \mathbf{Flight} \mathbf{Manual} \text{ (AFM)}$ and the $\mathbf{relevant} \mathbf{parts}$ of the $\mathbf{Operations} \mathbf{Manual}$ ($\text{OM}$) applicable to the duties of the crew are required to be carried on every commercial flight.

questions.question: 12. A $\mathbf{Flight} \mathbf{Data} \mathbf{Recorder} \text{ (FDR)}$ is required in aeroplanes over $5700 \text{ kg} \text{ when} \text{ first} \text{ issued} \text{ with} \text{ a} \text{ C} \text{ of} \text{ A} \mathbf{after} \mathbf{1st} \mathbf{April} \mathbf{1998}$. It must record:
options: the last $25 \text{ hours} \text{ or} \text{ the} \text{ duration} \text{ of} \text{ the} \text{ last} \text{ flight}, \text{ whichever} \text{ is} \text{ greater}$
the duration of the last flight
questions.explanation: For modern commercial aircraft, $\mathbf{FDR}$s must record a minimum of the $\mathbf{last} \mathbf{25} \mathbf{hours}$ of operational flight time.

questions.question: 13. If there is unauthorized use of equipment that $\mathbf{affects} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{aeroplane}'\mathbf{s} \mathbf{system}$, the commander:
options: may authorize its use for take-off and landing
may authorize its use for the whole flight
may authorize its use at his discretion
questions.explanation: Any item that $\mathbf{negatively} \mathbf{affects} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{safety} \mathbf{ of} \mathbf{flight}$ or aircraft systems $\mathbf{must} \mathbf{be} \mathbf{prohibited} \mathbf{from} \mathbf{use}$ by the commander.

questions.question: 14. Who $\mathbf{accepts} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{MEL}$?
options: The country where the flight takes place
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Authority} \mathbf{of} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{State} \mathbf{of} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{Operator}$ (the one that issues the $\text{AOC}$) is the body that must $\mathbf{approve} \text{ (accept)}$ the operator's $\mathbf{MEL}$.

questions.question: 15. After an $\mathbf{accident}$, the operator of an aeroplane equipped with a flight recorder must keep the original recordings for a minimum period of:
questions.explanation: Following an accident or incident, $\mathbf{ICAO} \mathbf{Annex} \mathbf{13}$ requires that the operator $\mathbf{preserve} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{recorded} \mathbf{data}$ for a minimum of $\mathbf{60} \mathbf{days}$ unless directed otherwise by the investigation authority.

questions.question: 16. How far away can a $\mathbf{take} \text{-}\mathbf{off} \mathbf{alternate}$ be for a $\mathbf{2} \text{-}\mathbf{engine} \mathbf{aeroplane}$?
options: 120 mins at one engine cruise speed
questions.explanation: A take-off alternate for a $\mathbf{two} \text{-}\mathbf{engine}$ aircraft must be located within $\mathbf{one} \mathbf{hour}$ $\mathbf{flying} \mathbf{time}$ at the $\mathbf{One} \mathbf{Engine} \mathbf{Inoperative} \text{ (OEI)}$ cruise speed.

questions.question: 17. What are the requirements for $\mathbf{pilot} \mathbf{currency}$ to act as $\text{PIC}$?
options: 3 take-offs and landings on an aeroplane of the same type within the last 90 days
3 take-offs and landings on an aeroplane of the same type within the last 60 days
3 take-offs and landings on an aeroplane of the same type or approved simulator within the last 60 days
questions.explanation: The standard pilot recent experience requirement is $\mathbf{3} \mathbf{take} \text{-}\mathbf{offs} \mathbf{and} \mathbf{landings}$ within the preceding $\mathbf{90} \mathbf{days}$ in the type, or in an $\mathbf{approved} \mathbf{flight} \mathbf{simulator}$.

questions.question: 18. All aeroplanes which individual certificates of airworthiness were issued $\mathbf{after} \mathbf{1} \mathbf{January} \mathbf{1990}$ must be fitted with a flight data recorder when their maximum certificated take-off mass is $\mathbf{greater} \mathbf{than}$:
questions.explanation: The threshold of $\mathbf{5,700} \mathbf{kg}$ $\mathbf{MTOM}$ is the historic and current minimum for requiring a $\mathbf{Flight} \mathbf{Data} \mathbf{Recorder} \text{ (FDR)}$ in turbine-powered commercial transport aeroplanes.

questions.question: 19. The operator shall include in the $\text{OM}$ a $\text{MEL}$ which shall be $\mathbf{approved} \mathbf{by} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{authority} \mathbf{of}$:
options: the country where the aeroplane is operated
the country where the aeroplane was manufactured
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{MEL}$ is approved by the same regulatory body that issues the $\mathbf{AOC} \text{ and} \mathbf{OM} \mathbf{approval}$, which is the $\mathbf{Authority} \mathbf{of} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{State} \mathbf{of} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{Operator}$.

questions.question: 20. A copy of which of the following must be carried on every flight involving $\mathbf{Public} \mathbf{Transport}$?
questions.explanation: The $\mathbf{Air} \mathbf{Operator}'\mathbf{s} \mathbf{Certificate} \text{ (AOC)}$, which authorises the commercial operation, or a copy thereof, is one of the essential documents required to be carried on every $\mathbf{Public} \mathbf{Transport}$ flight.

questions.question: 1. Which of the following are $\mathbf{not} \mathbf{required} \mathbf{to} \mathbf{be} \mathbf{carried}$ on each flight?
questions.explanation: While advisable for personal travel, the $\mathbf{EHIC}$ ($\text{or}$ any other personal health insurance document) is $\mathbf{not} \mathbf{a} \mathbf{mandatory} \mathbf{document}$ required by $\text{ICAO} \text{ or} \text{ EASA}$ to be carried $\mathbf{onboard} \mathbf{the} \mathbf{aircraft}$ for the operation of the flight. The other options are required documents or information for flight legality and safety.

questions.question: 1. An aeroplane is starting a non-precision approach with an MDH of 250 ft and minimum visibility of 800 m. ATC gives threshold, mid runway and final third RVRs. When may the approach be started?
options: When threshold and mid-runway RVRs are greater than 800 m
When all 3 RVRs are greater than 800 m
When the met viz is greater than 800 m. RVR is for precision approaches only
When threshold RVR is greater than 800 m
questions.explanation: For the initiation of a non-precision approach (NPA) when RVR is reported, the RVR must be at or above the required minimum (800 m). Standard procedures (like EASA/ICAO) often require the **threshold RVR** to be controlling for the purpose of starting the approach. While all available RVRs (Threshold and Mid-point) must be above the minimum for continuation below MDH, the most critical RVR for initiation is usually the threshold.

questions.question: 2. What is the Cat IIIB RVR minimum?
questions.explanation: Category III B approaches are defined by a Decision Height (DH) less than 50 ft or no DH, and an RVR less than 200 m, but **not less than 50 m**. 50 m RVR is the lowest published minimum for operational approval.

questions.question: 3. What is the minimum horizontal visibility for a Cat D aircraft on a circling approach?
questions.explanation: ICAO/EASA standard minimum visibility requirements for circling approaches, based on aircraft category, are: Cat A: 1500 m, Cat B: 1600 m, Cat C: 2400 m, Cat D: **3600 m**.

questions.question: 4. A category I precision approach (CAT I) is an approach which may be carried out with an RVR/Visibility of not less than:
questions.explanation: A Category I (CAT I) approach has a Decision Height (DH) of not less than 200 ft and an RVR/Visibility of not less than **550 m** (when using required lighting systems like High Intensity Runway Lights/Runway Centre Line Lights). 550 m is the most common and lowest minimum RVR for CAT I operations.

questions.question: 5. OPS 1.465 (VFR operating minima), establishes that, the operator shall ensure about VFR flights, that:
options: for conducted VFR flights in airspace F, vertical distance from clouds is 250 m at least
Special VFR flights are not commenced when visibility is less than 3 km
for conducted VFR flights in airspace B, horizontal distance from clouds is 1000 m at least
for conducted VFR flights in airspace E, flight visibility at and above 3050 m (10000 ft) is 5 km at least (clear of cloud)
questions.explanation: The standard ICAO VFR flight visibility is **5 km** below 10,000 ft MSL, and 8 km above. Option D, despite containing a confusing altitude reference ('at and above 3050 m'), is the only one citing the core 5 km visibility rule which is relevant to VFR minima in Class E airspace below 10,000 ft MSL. The other options cite incorrect separation or visibility values.

questions.question: 6. What is Vat?
options: The lesser of Vso or Vs1g
questions.explanation: The approach speed at the threshold (Vat), used for aircraft categorization (Cat A, B, C, D, E), is defined as the stalling speed in the landing configuration ($V_{S0}$) multiplied by a factor of **1.3**. This is the standard ICAO PANS-OPS definition for categorization.

questions.question: 7. The Cat I minimum decision height is:
questions.explanation: A Category I (CAT I) precision approach is defined by a Decision Height (DH) of **200 ft** or higher, and an RVR of not less than 550 m.

questions.question: 8. When establishing an instrument approach procedure, 5 aircraft categories according to their speed at the threshold (Vat) are established. This speed is equal to the stalling speed in landing configuration multiplied by:
questions.explanation: The factor used for determining the aircraft category (Vat) from the stalling speed ($V_{S0}$ or $V_{S1g}$) in the landing configuration is **1.3**.

questions.question: 9. For VFR flight (in a cat C aircraft) what is the minimum horizontal visibility below 10000 ft?
questions.explanation: VFR minima are based on airspace, not aircraft category. The standard minimum flight visibility below 10,000 ft MSL is **5 km** (with a few exceptions in less-controlled airspace and low altitudes).

questions.question: 10. The information to be considered for a non-precision approach is: 1. horizontal visibility 2. ceiling 3. minimum descent altitude 4. decision altitude
questions.explanation: Non-Precision Approaches (NPA) are governed by **Horizontal Visibility** (or RVR) (1) and a **Minimum Descent Altitude/Height (MDA/MDH)** (3). Ceiling is advisory, and Decision Altitude (DA) is used for Precision Approaches (PA).

questions.question: 11. What is the minimum crew rest period before flight?
options: 12 hours when operating away from home base
13 hours, reducing by 30 minutes for every sector after the 3rd sector in a day
10 hours when operating from home base
12 hours when operating from home base
questions.explanation: EASA Flight Time Limitation (FTL) rules define the minimum rest period to be at least **10 hours** in a 24-hour period. This is the absolute minimum rest required before a flight duty period.

questions.question: 12. Who could be nominated as Senior Cabin Crew?
options: Cabin crew with more than one year experience
Any cabin crew over the age of 18
Cabin crew as long as they are not qualified on more than 3 types or variants
questions.explanation: While the Senior Cabin Crew Member (SCCM) is designated based on training and competence, EASA operational regulations (CAT.OP.MPA.180) state that an operator shall not assign a cabin crew member to operate on more than **three types or variants** of aircraft. This is a definitive regulatory limit that all SCCMs must meet.

questions.question: 13. According to OPS 1.430 (Aerodrome Operating Minima) a Category IIIA approach has a Decision Height of less than 100 ft and a minimum RVR (Runway Visual Range) of:
questions.explanation: A Category III A (CAT IIIA) approach is defined by a Decision Height (DH) less than 100 ft and an RVR of not less than **200 m**.

questions.question: 14. Aircraft are categorized according to their threshold speeds, multiplied by a factor. What aircraft category corresponds to a range of speeds 141 kt - 165 kt?
questions.explanation: Aircraft Category D corresponds to a Vat (speed at threshold) range of **141 kt to 165 kt** (inclusive).

questions.question: 15. What are the rules regarding OPCs?
options: Can be completed in the simulator, but no passengers to be carried
Can be completed in the aircraft but only if the aircraft is certified by the Authority as a suitable substitute for the simulator
Can be completed in the simulator but only if the simulator is certified by the Authority
Can be completed in conjunction with a line check
questions.explanation: The Operator Proficiency Check (OPC) is an assessment of crew competency. It can be carried out in an approved Flight Simulation Training Device (FSTD) only if the FSTD is certified (approved) by the Authority to ensure it accurately replicates the aircraft and environment.

questions.question: 16. What are the threshold speeds defining a Cat B aircraft?
questions.explanation: Aircraft Category B corresponds to a Vat (speed at threshold) range of **91 kt to 120 kt** (inclusive).

questions.question: 17. What are the limits on crew duty?
options: 190 hours in a year, 60 duty hours in any seven consecutive days
900 block hours in a year, 60 block hours in any consecutive 7 days
900 block hours in a year, 100 block hours in any consecutive 28 days
190 block hours in any consecutive 7 days, 900 block hours in any consecutive 28 days
questions.explanation: Standard EASA/ICAO Flight Time Limitation (FTL) rules state that maximum flight time (block hours) is limited to **900 hours in a calendar year** and **100 hours in any 28 consecutive days**.

questions.question: 18. What is the take-off RVR limit for a Cat A aeroplane, when high intensity centre line lights and edge lights are on and the crew is IFR qualified and approved?
options: 150 m if threshold RVR is available
questions.explanation: With the required facilities (High Intensity Centre Line Lights and Edge Lights, and a suitably qualified crew), the minimum RVR for take-off is typically **150 m** for Cat A, B, C, and D aircraft. This minimum applies when at least two RVR reports (e.g., threshold and mid-point) are provided.

questions.question: 19. When is MDH referenced to the threshold as opposed to the aerodrome elevation?
options: The threshold is more than 2 m above the ARP
The threshold is less than 2 m above the ARP
The threshold is less than 2 m below the ARP
The threshold is more than 2 m below the ARP
questions.explanation: The Minimum Descent Height (MDH) for a non-precision approach is usually referenced to the aerodrome elevation (or Aerodrome Reference Point, ARP). However, it must be referenced to the **threshold elevation** when the threshold is $7\text{ ft}$ (approximately **2 m**) or more **below** the aerodrome elevation.

questions.question: 20. What is DH used for?
questions.explanation: Decision Height (DH) is the prescribed height at which a missed approach must be initiated if the required visual reference has not been established. DH is specifically used for **Precision Approaches (PA)** and Approach Procedures with Vertical Guidance (APV), as opposed to Minimum Descent Height (MDH) which is used for Non-Precision Approaches (NPA).

questions.question: When flying downwind abeam the upwind end of the runway the indications from the ILS on the CDI will be:

questions.question: MLS has 200 channels available in the frequency band:
questions.explanation: The Microwave Landing System (MLS) operates in the Super High Frequency (SHF) band between 5031 and 5090 MHz. This high frequency allows for greater accuracy and reduced siting issues compared to ILS.

questions.question: The time interval between the transmission of a pulse and receipt of the echo from a target is 925.5 microseconds. The range of the target is:
questions.explanation: The radar mile (round trip time) is 12.34 microseconds per Nautical Mile (NM).\nRange = Time / (12.34 µs/NM)\nRange = 925.5 µs / 12.34 µs/NM ≈ 75 NM.

questions.question: The best resolution will be obtained from:
options: a narrow beam width and narrow pulse width
a wide beam width and narrow pulse width
a narrow beam width and wide pulse width
a wide beam width and wide pulse width
questions.explanation: Angular resolution (distinguishing targets side-by-side) is improved by a **narrow beam width**. Range resolution (distinguishing targets in front of one another) is improved by a **narrow pulse width**.

questions.question: A precision approach runway CAT II is an instrument runway served by ILS and visual aids intended for operations down to:
options: a RVR of 550 meters and a DH of not less than 200 ft
a RVR of 200 meters and a DH of not less than 100 ft
a RVR of 250 meters and a DH of not less than 200 ft
a RVR of 300-450 meters and a DH of not less than 100 ft
questions.explanation: A CAT II approach is defined by a Decision Height (DH) lower than 200 ft but **not less than 100 ft** (or 30m) and a Runway Visual Range (RVR) of **not less than 300 m** (typically 300m to 450m depending on specific operational limits).

questions.question: The type of radar which has no minimum range restriction is:
questions.explanation: Primary **Pulsed Radar** has a minimum range limit because the receiver must be turned off while the transmitter is sending its powerful pulse. **Continuous Wave (CW) Radar** transmits and receives simultaneously, thus having no theoretical minimum range.

questions.question: An advantage of a slotted antenna (planar array) over a parabolic reflector are:
questions.explanation: Slotted antennas are preferred in modern radar systems, particularly for airborne weather radar, because they provide **higher gain** (more concentrated energy) and reduced side lobes compared to older parabolic designs.

questions.question: Refer to Appendix A, diagram B. What are the indications on the VOR/ILS display?
questions.explanation: As the diagram is missing, we will assume the correct configuration for this standard question. A setting of 210 with a FROM flag means the aircraft is on the 030° radial (flying away from 030) and the course deviation indicator (CDI) is commanding a turn to the left to intercept the selected course.

questions.question: Flying an ILS approach the equipment senses that the 90 Hz modulation predominates on both the localizer and the glide path. The indications the pilot will see are:
questions.explanation: On ILS:\n- **Localizer:** 90 Hz predominates on the **LEFT** side of the centreline. The CDI needle moves LEFT, commanding the pilot to fly **RIGHT**.\n- **Glide Path:** 90 Hz predominates **BELOW** the glide path. The glide path needle moves DOWN, commanding the pilot to fly **UP**.

questions.question: On a colour AWR display, the heaviest precipitation will be displayed in:
questions.explanation: Standard colour coding for Airborne Weather Radar (AWR) intensity:\nGreen = Light, Yellow/Amber = Moderate, **Red = Heavy** (often associated with severe turbulence and the highest threat).

questions.question: The coverage of the approach azimuth and elevation of a MLS is:
questions.explanation: The MLS approach azimuth coverage is $\\pm 40^{\\circ}$ horizontally, and the ICAO standard minimum range is **20 NM**.

questions.question: A radar transmitting on 600 MHz has a PRF of 300 pps and an aerial rotation rate of 5 rpm. This radar will be:
questions.explanation: A low frequency (600 MHz) and a low Pulse Repetition Frequency (PRF = 300 pps) result in a long maximum range ($\\approx 270$ NM). A low rotation rate (5 rpm) allows for multiple returns on a single target at long ranges. These characteristics are typical of an **Aerodrome/Air Surveillance Radar (ASR)**.

questions.question: The AWR operating frequency is:
questions.explanation: Airborne Weather Radar (AWR) operates in the X-band, which is approximately $9.375$ GHz. $9.375 \text{ GHz} = 9375 \text{ MHz}$.

questions.question: On an ILS approach, using a 3° glide path, the height of an aircraft, ground speed 160 kt, at 3.5 NM from touchdown should be:
questions.explanation: The rule of thumb for calculating height on a glide path is:\nHeight (ft) $\\approx$ Distance (NM) $\\times 100 \\times$ Glide Path Angle (degrees).\nHeight $\\approx 3.5 \text{ NM} \\times 100 \\times 3^{\\circ} = 1050 \text{ ft}$.

questions.question: The AWR frequency is selected because it gives:
questions.explanation: The X-band frequency (approx. 9.375 GHz) is highly sensitive to the size of water droplets and ice particles, making it effective at mapping out **precipitation** (good returns from water droplets).

questions.question: The azimuth coverage of a 3° glide path is:
questions.explanation: While the glide path signal may be available over the full localizer coverage, the protected area of the glide path signal is typically specified as $\\pm 8^{\\circ}$ up to 10 NM.

questions.question: The maximum theoretical range of a radar is determined by:
questions.explanation: The maximum unambiguous range ($R_{\\text{max}}$) is determined by the Pulse Repetition Frequency (PRF), specifically the time interval between pulses. $R_{\\text{max}} = c / (2 \\cdot \text{PRF})$ (where $c$ is the speed of light).

questions.question: In SSR the aircraft replies on .............. MHz and the ground station interrogates on ................. MHz
questions.explanation: Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR) uses two separate frequencies: The ground station **interrogates** the aircraft on **1030 MHz**, and the aircraft transponder **replies** on **1090 MHz**.

questions.question: A full MLS system comprises a DME and:
questions.explanation: A basic MLS provides Azimuth and Elevation guidance. These two main angular guidance elements (AZ & EL) use Time Division Multiplexing (TDM) to operate within a single frequency band (5031-5090 MHz), hence '2 elements multiplexing on one frequency' (band).

questions.question: If the signal from an SV is lost during an aircraft manoeuvre:
options: the receiver will select another SV with no loss in accuracy
the receiver will go into a DR mode with no loss of accuracy
the receiver will compensate by using the last calculated altitude to maintain positional accuracy
the receiver position will degrade regardless of the action taken
questions.explanation: Losing an SV (Satellite Vehicle) immediately compromises the **Geometry** of the fix, causing the Dilution of Precision (DOP) to increase. The positional accuracy will inherently degrade, as the receiver's ability to compute a precise position is reduced, regardless of internal compensation mechanisms like using barometric altitude.

questions.question: The navigation database in an FMC:
options: can be modified by the flight crew to meet the route requirements
can only be read by the flight crew
cannot be accessed by the flight crew
questions.explanation: The core navigation database (containing navaids, airways, airports, etc.) is a protected, **read-only** data source provided by third-party suppliers (like Jeppesen) and loaded every 28 days. The flight crew can only access and use this information to build a flight plan; they cannot modify the fundamental database entries.

questions.question: If the receiver almanac becomes corrupted it will download the almanac from the constellation. This download will take:
questions.explanation: The complete GPS almanac consists of 25 "pages" of data (in subframes 4 and 5 of the Navigation Message). Each page takes 30 seconds to transmit at the low data rate of 50 bits per second. Therefore, $25 \text{ pages} \times 30 \text{ seconds/page} = 750 \text{ seconds}$, which is exactly **12.5 minutes**.

questions.question: The optimum position for a DME aerial on an aircraft is:
options: in the nose cone to give maximum forward range
as close to the fore/aft centre line as possible
on top of the fuselage close to the wings
close to each wing tip to compensate for manoeuvre errors
questions.explanation: The optimal position for a DME antenna is along the **fore/aft centre line** (usually on the underside of the fuselage) to minimize shadowing from the aircraft structure, especially during banked turns, ensuring the most consistent all-around reception pattern.

questions.question: The most accurate external reference position will be provided by:
options: Suitable combination of VOR and DME
questions.explanation: A position fix calculated from the intersection of two **DME** (Distance Measuring Equipment) range arcs is generally the most accurate of the conventional radio navigation fixes. DME has superior accuracy compared to the angular measurement of a VOR. This method is commonly used by FMCs for RNAV position updating.

questions.question: A DME recognizes replies to its own interrogating pulses because:
options: each pulse pair has its own unique modulation which is replicated by the transponder
the PRF of the interrogating pulses is jittered
each aircraft has a different time interval within the pulses pairs which is replicated by the transponder
the transponder uses a selective reply system to respond to the aircraft interrogation pulses
questions.explanation: Each aircraft's DME interrogator transmits a unique, slightly randomized sequence of pulse pairs known as a **'jittered' Pulse Repetition Frequency (PRF)**. The transponder replies to *all* interrogations, and the aircraft receiver identifies the replies belonging to it by correlating the arrival timing pattern with the specific PRF it transmitted.

questions.question: The RNAV function of the FMC produces a position which:
options: combines the short term accuracy of the external reference with the long term accuracy of the IRS
produces a long term accuracy from the short term accuracy of the external references
combines the long term accuracy of the external reference with the short term accuracy of the IRS
relies solely on the IRS position
questions.explanation: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) uses a blend of data. The **Inertial Reference System (IRS)** provides excellent **short-term** data (instantaneous velocity/attitude). The **external radio references (VOR/DME, DME/DME)** provide precise position fixes to correct the IRS drift, thus providing **long-term** accuracy. The FMC combines the strengths of both.

questions.question: If the identification of a VOR is FKL and the paired DME identification is FKZ, then:
options: the beacons are between 600 m and 6 NM apart
the transmitters are in excess of 6 NM apart
questions.explanation: ICAO rules state that for a VOR and DME to be considered **co-located** and assigned the same identifier (e.g., FKL/FKL), they must be very close (usually within 30m to 100m, or 600m max in some older contexts). Since the identifiers are **dissimilar** (FKL and FKZ), they are not considered co-located but are likely an associated pair, meaning they are separated but still close enough to be used together for navigation, typically falling into a bracket like **600 m to 6 NM**.

questions.question: The NAVSTAR/GPS operational constellation comprises:
questions.explanation: The minimum required operational constellation for GPS is **24 satellites (SV)**, distributed in **6 orbital planes**. This design ensures at least 4 SVs are visible from almost any point on Earth at any time.

questions.question: The model of the earth used for GPS is:
questions.explanation: The standard datum (geodetic model) used by the Global Positioning System (GPS) for all its calculations, satellite positions, and user coordinates is the **World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84)**.

questions.question: EGNOS provides a WAAS by determining the errors in ................ and broadcasting these errors to receivers using ................
options: X, Y & Z coordinates geostationary satellites
questions.explanation: EGNOS (European Geostationary Navigation Overlay Service), which is a regional version of WAAS (Wide Area Augmentation System), determines the errors affecting the signal travel time (the **SV range** or pseudorange) and broadcasts these corrections to user receivers via **Geostationary Satellites**.

questions.question: If the aircraft DME interrogates a ground transponder on a frequency of 1199 MHz, it will receive replies on:
questions.explanation: DME systems use paired frequencies separated by 63 MHz. The aircraft transmits (interrogates) and the ground station replies. For X channels, if the interrogation frequency is in the high band (above 1150 MHz), the reply frequency is 63 MHz lower. Calculation: $1199 \text{ MHz} - 63 \text{ MHz} = \mathbf{1136 \text{ MHz}}$.

questions.question: The purpose of the PRN codes in NAVSTAR/GPS is to:
options: synchronize the receiver clocks with the SV clocks
pass navigation and system data to the receiver
questions.explanation: The Pseudo-Random Noise (PRN) codes are critical for the GPS system: they provide a unique signature for the receiver to **identify** which satellite is transmitting, they are used to compute the travel time of the signal to determine range (pseudorange), and they allow the receiver to align its clock (synchronize) with the signal. The codes enable all the stated functions.

questions.question: The provision of RAIM requires a minimum of ................ SVs
questions.explanation: A standard 3D fix requires 4 satellites (to solve for Lat, Lon, Alt, and Time). **RAIM** (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring) requires an additional, redundant satellite measurement to check the solution for integrity. Therefore, the minimum number of satellites required for RAIM is 4 (for the fix) + 1 (for the check) = **5 SVs**.

questions.question: The principle error in GNSS is:
questions.explanation: The largest source of error in the GPS signal, which is not fully compensated for by a basic receiver, is the variable delay caused by the **Ionosphere**. This can introduce signal timing errors equivalent to tens of meters in position.

questions.question: The number of SVs required to produce a 3D fix is:
questions.explanation: A 3D (three-dimensional) position fix requires solving for four unknowns: Latitude, Longitude, Altitude (position), and Receiver Clock Error. To solve for four unknowns, a minimum of **4 satellites (SVs)** are required.

The altitude read-out at the ground station from a mode C response will give the aircraft altitude within:
questions.explanation: Mode C transponders report pressure altitude in standard **100-foot increments**. Therefore, the resolution of the altitude data provided to the ground station (ATC) is limited to the nearest 100 feet.

questions.question: 3. The main advantage of a continuous wave radar over a pulsed radar is:
options: more complex equipment but better resolution and accuracy
permits measurement of Doppler in addition to improved range and bearing
questions.explanation: Continuous Wave (CW) radar is unique because it can measure the Doppler shift (change in frequency) between the transmitted and received signals. This shift is directly proportional to the target's radial velocity (speed towards or away from the radar).

questions.question: 4. For a conventional VOR a phase difference of 090° would be achieved by flying............... from the beacon:
questions.explanation: The VOR radial is the magnetic track FROM the beacon. A phase difference of $090^\circ$ between the variable and reference phase signals corresponds exactly to the 090° magnetic radial , which is due East.

questions.question: 5. The ILS glide slope transmitter generates false glide slope signals:
questions.explanation: False glide slope signals are created by ground reflections and are always located at angles higher than the true, desired glide slope (e.g., $6^\circ, 9^\circ$). This is why pilots are instructed to intercept the true glide slope from a position below it.

questions.question: 6. At a range of 200 NM from a VOR, if there is an error of 1°, how far off the centre line is the aircraft?
questions.explanation: The distance off course can be calculated using the 1-in-60 rule (or small angle approximation): $\text{Distance Off} \approx \frac{\text{Angular Error (degrees)} \times \text{Distance (NM)}}{60}$ $\text{Distance Off} \approx \frac{1^\circ \times 200 \text{ NM}}{60} = 3.33 \text{ NM}$ The closest answer is 3.5 NM .

questions.question: 7. The coverage of the ILS glide slope with respect to the localizer centre line is:
questions.explanation: ICAO minimum standards require the ILS Glide Slope signal to provide adequate coverage laterally to $\pm 8^\circ$ from the localizer centre line, and longitudinally out to a range of 10 NM .

questions.question: 9. The principle of operation of the ILS localizer transmitter is that it transmits two overlapping lobes on:
options: the same frequency with different phases
the same frequency with different amplitude modulations
different frequencies with different amplitude modulations
questions.explanation: The ILS Localizer operates using the Difference in Depth of Modulation (DDM) principle. It transmits two overlapping lobes on a single carrier frequency : one modulated at $90 \text{ Hz}$ (left of track) and one modulated at $150 \text{ Hz}$ (right of track). The aircraft determines its position by comparing the strength of these two amplitude modulations.

questions.question: 10. The amplitude modulation of the ILS outer marker is ............... and it illuminates the................light in the cockpit.
questions.explanation: The Outer Marker (OM) is modulated at a low tone of 400 Hz (continuous dashes) and illuminates the blue light on the marker beacon receiver panel.

questions.question: 11. Which of the following systems use pulse technique? 1. secondary surveillance radar 2. airborne weather radar 3. distance measuring equipment 4. primary radar
questions.explanation: All listed systems determine range by measuring the time delay between transmitting a pulse and receiving a return (either an echo, for primary/weather radar, or a reply, for SSR/DME).

13. In which frequency band does ILS operate?
questions.explanation: The ILS system uses two different frequency bands: the Localizer operates in the VHF band, and the Glide Slope operates in the UHF band.

questions.question: 14. Distance on MLS is measured by:
options: measuring the time taken for the primary radar pulse to travel from the MLS transmitter to the aircraft receiver
measuring the time taken for the secondary radar pulse to travel from the MLS transmitter to the aircraft receiver
phase comparison between the azimuth and elevation beams
questions.explanation: The Microwave Landing System (MLS) provides azimuth and elevation using scanning beams, but it does not intrinsically provide range information. Distance is provided by a **co-located Distance Measuring Equipment (DME)**, often a precision DME (DME/P).

questions.question: 15. The coverage of MLS is ............... either side of the centre line to a distance of...............
questions.explanation: The ICAO standard for MLS Azimuth coverage is $\pm 40^\circ$ either side of the center line, out to a range of at least 20 NM .

questions.question: 16. In which band does the ILS glide path operate?
questions.explanation: The ILS Glide Path operates in the UHF frequency band (approximately 330 MHz). The UHF band corresponds to wavelengths between 1 meter and 1 decimeter (10 cm), which is known as the decimetric wave band.

questions.explanation: Angular/Bearing Resolution: Requires a narrow beamwidth to separate targets close together in bearing. questions.question: 19. Primary radar operates on the principle of:
questions.explanation: The most common form of primary radar operates by transmitting high-energy **pulses** and receiving the reflected energy (echoes). Range is calculated by measuring the time delay between transmission and reception.

questions.explanation: The Microwave Landing System (MLS) operates in the Super High Frequency (SHF) band between 5031 and 5090 MHz. This high frequency allows for greater accuracy and reduced siting issues compared to ILS.

questions.question: The time interval between the transmission of a pulse and receipt of the echo from a target is 925.5 microseconds. The range of the target is:
questions.explanation: The radar mile (round trip time) is 12.34 microseconds per Nautical Mile (NM).\nRange = Time / (12.34 µs/NM)\nRange = 925.5 µs / 12.34 µs/NM ≈ 75 NM.

questions.question: The best resolution will be obtained from:
options: a narrow beam width and narrow pulse width
a wide beam width and narrow pulse width
a narrow beam width and wide pulse width
a wide beam width and wide pulse width
questions.explanation: Angular resolution (distinguishing targets side-by-side) is improved by a **narrow beam width**. Range resolution (distinguishing targets in front of one another) is improved by a **narrow pulse width**.
