questions.question: A precision approach runway CAT II is an instrument runway served by ILS and visual aids intended for operations down to:
options: a RVR of 550 meters and a DH of not less than 200 ft
a RVR of 200 meters and a DH of not less than 100 ft
a RVR of 250 meters and a DH of not less than 200 ft
a RVR of 300-450 meters and a DH of not less than 100 ft
questions.explanation: A CAT II approach is defined by a Decision Height (DH) lower than 200 ft but **not less than 100 ft** (or 30m) and a Runway Visual Range (RVR) of **not less than 300 m** (typically 300m to 450m depending on specific operational limits).

questions.question: The type of radar which has no minimum range restriction is:
questions.explanation: Primary **Pulsed Radar** has a minimum range limit because the receiver must be turned off while the transmitter is sending its powerful pulse. **Continuous Wave (CW) Radar** transmits and receives simultaneously, thus having no theoretical minimum range.

questions.question: An advantage of a slotted antenna (planar array) over a parabolic reflector are:
questions.explanation: Slotted antennas are preferred in modern radar systems, particularly for airborne weather radar, because they provide **higher gain** (more concentrated energy) and reduced side lobes compared to older parabolic designs.

questions.question: Refer to Appendix A, diagram B. What are the indications on the VOR/ILS display?
questions.explanation: As the diagram is missing, we will assume the correct configuration for this standard question. A setting of 210 with a FROM flag means the aircraft is on the 030° radial (flying away from 030) and the course deviation indicator (CDI) is commanding a turn to the left to intercept the selected course.

questions.question: Flying an ILS approach the equipment senses that the 90 Hz modulation predominates on both the localizer and the glide path. The indications the pilot will see are:
questions.explanation: On ILS:\n- **Localizer:** 90 Hz predominates on the **LEFT** side of the centreline. The CDI needle moves LEFT, commanding the pilot to fly **RIGHT**.\n- **Glide Path:** 90 Hz predominates **BELOW** the glide path. The glide path needle moves DOWN, commanding the pilot to fly **UP**.

questions.question: On a colour AWR display, the heaviest precipitation will be displayed in:
questions.explanation: Standard colour coding for Airborne Weather Radar (AWR) intensity:\nGreen = Light, Yellow/Amber = Moderate, **Red = Heavy** (often associated with severe turbulence and the highest threat).

questions.question: The coverage of the approach azimuth and elevation of a MLS is:
questions.explanation: The MLS approach azimuth coverage is $\\pm 40^{\\circ}$ horizontally, and the ICAO standard minimum range is **20 NM**.

questions.question: A radar transmitting on 600 MHz has a PRF of 300 pps and an aerial rotation rate of 5 rpm. This radar will be:
questions.explanation: A low frequency (600 MHz) and a low Pulse Repetition Frequency (PRF = 300 pps) result in a long maximum range ($\\approx 270$ NM). A low rotation rate (5 rpm) allows for multiple returns on a single target at long ranges. These characteristics are typical of an **Aerodrome/Air Surveillance Radar (ASR)**.

questions.question: The AWR operating frequency is:
questions.explanation: Airborne Weather Radar (AWR) operates in the X-band, which is approximately $9.375$ GHz. $9.375 \text{ GHz} = 9375 \text{ MHz}$.

questions.question: On an ILS approach, using a 3° glide path, the height of an aircraft, ground speed 160 kt, at 3.5 NM from touchdown should be:
questions.explanation: The rule of thumb for calculating height on a glide path is:\nHeight (ft) $\\approx$ Distance (NM) $\\times 100 \\times$ Glide Path Angle (degrees).\nHeight $\\approx 3.5 \text{ NM} \\times 100 \\times 3^{\\circ} = 1050 \text{ ft}$.

questions.question: The AWR frequency is selected because it gives:
questions.explanation: The X-band frequency (approx. 9.375 GHz) is highly sensitive to the size of water droplets and ice particles, making it effective at mapping out **precipitation** (good returns from water droplets).

questions.question: The azimuth coverage of a 3° glide path is:
questions.explanation: While the glide path signal may be available over the full localizer coverage, the protected area of the glide path signal is typically specified as $\\pm 8^{\\circ}$ up to 10 NM.

questions.question: The maximum theoretical range of a radar is determined by:
questions.explanation: The maximum unambiguous range ($R_{\\text{max}}$) is determined by the Pulse Repetition Frequency (PRF), specifically the time interval between pulses. $R_{\\text{max}} = c / (2 \\cdot \text{PRF})$ (where $c$ is the speed of light).

questions.question: In SSR the aircraft replies on .............. MHz and the ground station interrogates on ................. MHz
questions.explanation: Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR) uses two separate frequencies: The ground station **interrogates** the aircraft on **1030 MHz**, and the aircraft transponder **replies** on **1090 MHz**.

questions.question: A full MLS system comprises a DME and:
questions.explanation: A basic MLS provides Azimuth and Elevation guidance. These two main angular guidance elements (AZ & EL) use Time Division Multiplexing (TDM) to operate within a single frequency band (5031-5090 MHz), hence '2 elements multiplexing on one frequency' (band).

questions.question: If the signal from an SV is lost during an aircraft manoeuvre:
options: the receiver will select another SV with no loss in accuracy
the receiver will go into a DR mode with no loss of accuracy
the receiver will compensate by using the last calculated altitude to maintain positional accuracy
the receiver position will degrade regardless of the action taken
questions.explanation: Losing an SV (Satellite Vehicle) immediately compromises the **Geometry** of the fix, causing the Dilution of Precision (DOP) to increase. The positional accuracy will inherently degrade, as the receiver's ability to compute a precise position is reduced, regardless of internal compensation mechanisms like using barometric altitude.

questions.question: The navigation database in an FMC:
options: can be modified by the flight crew to meet the route requirements
can only be read by the flight crew
cannot be accessed by the flight crew
questions.explanation: The core navigation database (containing navaids, airways, airports, etc.) is a protected, **read-only** data source provided by third-party suppliers (like Jeppesen) and loaded every 28 days. The flight crew can only access and use this information to build a flight plan; they cannot modify the fundamental database entries.

questions.question: If the receiver almanac becomes corrupted it will download the almanac from the constellation. This download will take:
questions.explanation: The complete GPS almanac consists of 25 "pages" of data (in subframes 4 and 5 of the Navigation Message). Each page takes 30 seconds to transmit at the low data rate of 50 bits per second. Therefore, $25 \text{ pages} \times 30 \text{ seconds/page} = 750 \text{ seconds}$, which is exactly **12.5 minutes**.

questions.question: The optimum position for a DME aerial on an aircraft is:
options: in the nose cone to give maximum forward range
as close to the fore/aft centre line as possible
on top of the fuselage close to the wings
close to each wing tip to compensate for manoeuvre errors
questions.explanation: The optimal position for a DME antenna is along the **fore/aft centre line** (usually on the underside of the fuselage) to minimize shadowing from the aircraft structure, especially during banked turns, ensuring the most consistent all-around reception pattern.

questions.question: The most accurate external reference position will be provided by:
options: Suitable combination of VOR and DME
questions.explanation: A position fix calculated from the intersection of two **DME** (Distance Measuring Equipment) range arcs is generally the most accurate of the conventional radio navigation fixes. DME has superior accuracy compared to the angular measurement of a VOR. This method is commonly used by FMCs for RNAV position updating.

questions.question: A DME recognizes replies to its own interrogating pulses because:
options: each pulse pair has its own unique modulation which is replicated by the transponder
the PRF of the interrogating pulses is jittered
each aircraft has a different time interval within the pulses pairs which is replicated by the transponder
the transponder uses a selective reply system to respond to the aircraft interrogation pulses
questions.explanation: Each aircraft's DME interrogator transmits a unique, slightly randomized sequence of pulse pairs known as a **'jittered' Pulse Repetition Frequency (PRF)**. The transponder replies to *all* interrogations, and the aircraft receiver identifies the replies belonging to it by correlating the arrival timing pattern with the specific PRF it transmitted.

questions.question: The RNAV function of the FMC produces a position which:
options: combines the short term accuracy of the external reference with the long term accuracy of the IRS
produces a long term accuracy from the short term accuracy of the external references
combines the long term accuracy of the external reference with the short term accuracy of the IRS
relies solely on the IRS position
questions.explanation: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) uses a blend of data. The **Inertial Reference System (IRS)** provides excellent **short-term** data (instantaneous velocity/attitude). The **external radio references (VOR/DME, DME/DME)** provide precise position fixes to correct the IRS drift, thus providing **long-term** accuracy. The FMC combines the strengths of both.

questions.question: If the identification of a VOR is FKL and the paired DME identification is FKZ, then:
options: the beacons are between 600 m and 6 NM apart
the transmitters are in excess of 6 NM apart
questions.explanation: ICAO rules state that for a VOR and DME to be considered **co-located** and assigned the same identifier (e.g., FKL/FKL), they must be very close (usually within 30m to 100m, or 600m max in some older contexts). Since the identifiers are **dissimilar** (FKL and FKZ), they are not considered co-located but are likely an associated pair, meaning they are separated but still close enough to be used together for navigation, typically falling into a bracket like **600 m to 6 NM**.

questions.question: The NAVSTAR/GPS operational constellation comprises:
questions.explanation: The minimum required operational constellation for GPS is **24 satellites (SV)**, distributed in **6 orbital planes**. This design ensures at least 4 SVs are visible from almost any point on Earth at any time.

questions.question: The model of the earth used for GPS is:
questions.explanation: The standard datum (geodetic model) used by the Global Positioning System (GPS) for all its calculations, satellite positions, and user coordinates is the **World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84)**.

questions.question: EGNOS provides a WAAS by determining the errors in ................ and broadcasting these errors to receivers using ................
options: X, Y & Z coordinates geostationary satellites
questions.explanation: EGNOS (European Geostationary Navigation Overlay Service), which is a regional version of WAAS (Wide Area Augmentation System), determines the errors affecting the signal travel time (the **SV range** or pseudorange) and broadcasts these corrections to user receivers via **Geostationary Satellites**.

questions.question: If the aircraft DME interrogates a ground transponder on a frequency of 1199 MHz, it will receive replies on:
questions.explanation: DME systems use paired frequencies separated by 63 MHz. The aircraft transmits (interrogates) and the ground station replies. For X channels, if the interrogation frequency is in the high band (above 1150 MHz), the reply frequency is 63 MHz lower. Calculation: $1199 \text{ MHz} - 63 \text{ MHz} = \mathbf{1136 \text{ MHz}}$.

questions.question: The purpose of the PRN codes in NAVSTAR/GPS is to:
options: synchronize the receiver clocks with the SV clocks
pass navigation and system data to the receiver
questions.explanation: The Pseudo-Random Noise (PRN) codes are critical for the GPS system: they provide a unique signature for the receiver to **identify** which satellite is transmitting, they are used to compute the travel time of the signal to determine range (pseudorange), and they allow the receiver to align its clock (synchronize) with the signal. The codes enable all the stated functions.

questions.question: The provision of RAIM requires a minimum of ................ SVs
questions.explanation: A standard 3D fix requires 4 satellites (to solve for Lat, Lon, Alt, and Time). **RAIM** (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring) requires an additional, redundant satellite measurement to check the solution for integrity. Therefore, the minimum number of satellites required for RAIM is 4 (for the fix) + 1 (for the check) = **5 SVs**.

questions.question: The principle error in GNSS is:
questions.explanation: The largest source of error in the GPS signal, which is not fully compensated for by a basic receiver, is the variable delay caused by the **Ionosphere**. This can introduce signal timing errors equivalent to tens of meters in position.

questions.question: The number of SVs required to produce a 3D fix is:
questions.explanation: A 3D (three-dimensional) position fix requires solving for four unknowns: Latitude, Longitude, Altitude (position), and Receiver Clock Error. To solve for four unknowns, a minimum of **4 satellites (SVs)** are required.

The altitude read-out at the ground station from a mode C response will give the aircraft altitude within:
questions.explanation: Mode C transponders report pressure altitude in standard **100-foot increments**. Therefore, the resolution of the altitude data provided to the ground station (ATC) is limited to the nearest 100 feet.

questions.question: 3. The main advantage of a continuous wave radar over a pulsed radar is:
options: more complex equipment but better resolution and accuracy
permits measurement of Doppler in addition to improved range and bearing
questions.explanation: Continuous Wave (CW) radar is unique because it can measure the Doppler shift (change in frequency) between the transmitted and received signals. This shift is directly proportional to the target's radial velocity (speed towards or away from the radar).

questions.explanation: The VOR radial is the magnetic track FROM the beacon. A phase difference of $090^\circ$ between the variable and reference phase signals corresponds exactly to the 090° magnetic radial , which is due East.

questions.question: 5. The ILS glide slope transmitter generates false glide slope signals:
questions.explanation: False glide slope signals are created by ground reflections and are always located at angles higher than the true, desired glide slope (e.g., $6^\circ, 9^\circ$). This is why pilots are instructed to intercept the true glide slope from a position below it.

questions.question: 6. At a range of 200 NM from a VOR, if there is an error of 1°, how far off the centre line is the aircraft?
questions.explanation: The distance off course can be calculated using the 1-in-60 rule (or small angle approximation): $\text{Distance Off} \approx \frac{\text{Angular Error (degrees)} \times \text{Distance (NM)}}{60}$ $\text{Distance Off} \approx \frac{1^\circ \times 200 \text{ NM}}{60} = 3.33 \text{ NM}$ The closest answer is 3.5 NM .

questions.question: 7. The coverage of the ILS glide slope with respect to the localizer centre line is:
questions.explanation: ICAO minimum standards require the ILS Glide Slope signal to provide adequate coverage laterally to $\pm 8^\circ$ from the localizer centre line, and longitudinally out to a range of 10 NM .

questions.question: 9. The principle of operation of the ILS localizer transmitter is that it transmits two overlapping lobes on:
options: the same frequency with different phases
the same frequency with different amplitude modulations
different frequencies with different amplitude modulations
questions.explanation: The ILS Localizer operates using the Difference in Depth of Modulation (DDM) principle. It transmits two overlapping lobes on a single carrier frequency : one modulated at $90 \text{ Hz}$ (left of track) and one modulated at $150 \text{ Hz}$ (right of track). The aircraft determines its position by comparing the strength of these two amplitude modulations.

questions.question: 10. The amplitude modulation of the ILS outer marker is ............... and it illuminates the................light in the cockpit.
questions.explanation: The Outer Marker (OM) is modulated at a low tone of 400 Hz (continuous dashes) and illuminates the blue light on the marker beacon receiver panel.

questions.question: 11. Which of the following systems use pulse technique? 1. secondary surveillance radar 2. airborne weather radar 3. distance measuring equipment 4. primary radar
questions.explanation: All listed systems determine range by measuring the time delay between transmitting a pulse and receiving a return (either an echo, for primary/weather radar, or a reply, for SSR/DME).

13. In which frequency band does ILS operate?
questions.explanation: The ILS system uses two different frequency bands: the Localizer operates in the VHF band, and the Glide Slope operates in the UHF band.

questions.question: 14. Distance on MLS is measured by:
options: measuring the time taken for the primary radar pulse to travel from the MLS transmitter to the aircraft receiver
measuring the time taken for the secondary radar pulse to travel from the MLS transmitter to the aircraft receiver
phase comparison between the azimuth and elevation beams
questions.explanation: The Microwave Landing System (MLS) provides azimuth and elevation using scanning beams, but it does not intrinsically provide range information. Distance is provided by a **co-located Distance Measuring Equipment (DME)**, often a precision DME (DME/P).

questions.question: 15. The coverage of MLS is ............... either side of the centre line to a distance of...............
questions.explanation: The ICAO standard for MLS Azimuth coverage is $\pm 40^\circ$ either side of the center line, out to a range of at least 20 NM .

questions.question: 16. In which band does the ILS glide path operate?
questions.explanation: The ILS Glide Path operates in the UHF frequency band (approximately 330 MHz). The UHF band corresponds to wavelengths between 1 meter and 1 decimeter (10 cm), which is known as the decimetric wave band.

questions.question: 18. The definition of a radar display will be best with:
questions.explanation: Angular/Bearing Resolution: Requires a narrow beamwidth to separate targets close together in bearing. questions.question: 19. Primary radar operates on the principle of:
questions.explanation: The most common form of primary radar operates by transmitting high-energy **pulses** and receiving the reflected energy (echoes). Range is calculated by measuring the time delay between transmission and reception.
